review: Early indie roguelite that attempts to translate the brutal physicality and procedure of games like Spelunky and Nuclear Throne to a pure FPS format, with a striking visual and aural identity. Has its limitations for sure, but considering the projects its designers would later be involved in, this is an interesting piece of game design.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029170410', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1656029544}
review:
This is a fun game to play. It doesn't have to get more complicated than that. In a nutshell, its a procedurally generated labyrinth full of monsters. You've got a gun, and a handful of bullets. Anytime you shoot one, you have to pick it back up, and reload it. It's such a simple mechanic and you wouldn't think that would make the game fun, but it does. 

Personally, I have not beaten the game. I've gotten close, and I think I could manage it with luck and time. This is a great couch game between friends. Give it a run, pass it to a friend. Or play it solo and build a few runs your way. 

Downside, the game is short. The development is over. There is no news of a sequel or updates. I come back to this game from time to time and am reluctant to finally beat it for this reason.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984338378', 'num_games_owned': 829, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1702431285}
review:
I bought Heavy Bullets somewhere around 8 years prior to writing this review. I clocked most of my time during that time in 2015, then a little bit recently. I think I got my money's worth (sale + already cheap indie game) but I think my opinion on Heavy Bullets has remained the same: interesting idea, tedious in gameplay past the first two hours.

The only thing that's memorable about the game is its defining mechanic: if you shoot a bullet, it lands on the ground and you can pick it up again. The levels are just hallway mazes without changes in elevation and the challenge of the game relies on placing enemies at distance so it's harder to hit weakpoints and around corners as jumpscares. That would be fine if it was part of some bigger enemy pool and level design, but you essentially play the same encounter over and over again per run. There's some minute change in terms of enemy introduction if you're playing the game for the first time, but it's really insignificant.

The game is about 9 years old so I don't feel guilty spoiling the final boss: it's a monster that doesn't do anything in a narrow room of turrets and fodder enemies. You need to do a few runs to internalize the general pattern of the boss room because half the challenge is disabling the movement-hampering turrets so you can actually deal with everything else, then the other half is cleaning up the turrets. Again, you're essentially playing the same encounter over the course of each level.

Bad games are at least memorable because of the circus of errors that make up the game. Heavy Bullets is average and extremely forgettable; nothing about it is glaringly bad, but nothing about it is exceptional, unique, or interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009546644', 'num_games_owned': 519, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1700476914}
review:
This is a nice rogue-lite, although, I wish the devs would come back to it and make a sequel because there is a few flaws in it and I feel like a sequel would make this game better if some ideas can be fleshed out more and certain things be fixed. Not only that but I wish they would come back to this game and fix a few bugs and fine tune certain things that can sort of make people not enjoy the game so much.

For starters, its an FPS rogue-lite where you have a revolver with 6 bullets and when you shoot them you can pick them back up, which is a pretty cool concept. The graphics and details are simplistic but vibrant and there's not a lot of detail to levels and enemies overall but that's not a bad thing. If you're a fan of the Sludgelife OST you can say this is like a prequel to it, although I wish the music would play the whole time, since it only starts playing when you are in combat. The game has 8 levels (8 floors) in total that you have to do in one go, it lets you save and quit but only after you beat a floor. Overall its a pretty cool experience, its fun and I think you should give it a try!  

Ok, so whats wrong with it? Well...

I feel like this game has the same issue I had with Superhot MCD. Its a rogue-LITE. The rogue elements are there but it needs to be a little deeper at least for me to be able to enjoy it more than what it puts out.

I like the simplistic design of the game as a whole and everything, low poly is my jam, but you don't get a lot of difference between each level. The biggest difference is that it gets darker the deeper you go and you start to see a bit more panels with buttons on the wall and some pipes, but that's about it. If they can make each level a bit more distinct or at least change the color palettes or something, then it would keep you engaged as you see how much each floor changes (or at least make it look a bit more differently after reaching the midpoint). 

Not only that but I feel like the levels were a bit too long, I think if they would shorten the length of each floor by a bit, the game would have much better pacing and it wouldn't feel so detrimental to die in a run.

The enemy variety is fine, it ranges from animals to bugs to turrets... and damn, those turrets are killer. Sometimes they would shoot me as soon as they see me, other times it would take them a while and almost every time I try to peek the corner just so i can get a shot and kill it before it shoots me, 9 times out of 10 it always instantaneously shot me so i would take a hit. The hit-boxes for turrets are definitely funky on them sometimes when trying to kill them too, but it didn't happen to me that often with the regular turrets. [spoiler] However, when the game introduces the walking and even worse the flying turrets, the bugs started to show more, some turrets that walk/fly up to you would just shoot you every single time you peek a corner like if they had no cool down, which makes cornering encounters extremely dangerous.[/spoiler] Sometimes my bullets wouldn't kill them when I clearly shot them on their weak spot or they would somehow get to shoot me as soon as they died and end up hurting me. [spoiler] Not only that but there was certain occasions where 2 flying turrets somehow went inside the walls and started shooting at me, killing me and ending my run at floor 7. Not very fun! [/spoiler] There were also times where some turrets would be able to shoot me through the corners of the wall as I was trying to peak them so I can kill them, which happened to me so often that I ultimately didn't do that anymore and just tried to kill them as fast as possible when exposing myself to them. 

The midway boss and end boss do not change at all, which makes it lack in variety but at least doing them multiple times helps you learn a good strategy to kill them. [spoiler] There is also like a mini-boss in the 7th floor that you have to kill by hitting a switch in the room, that definitely caught me by surprise. [/spoiler]

You have 5 upgrades you can buy for yourself that permanently boost certain stats but I really didn't find a use in any of them besides for Maximum Health Upgrade and Reload+. Sometimes Carry+ but I never bought it for these reasons, you only have 1 inventory slot and you can only get a second slot if you find and purchase the backpack, which allows you to carry Items, but Carry+ does not affect the backpack but instead the individual items that go in the slots.

Some Items as well would of worked better off as just permanent upgrades instead of something you have to carry, like the scope could of just been something that attaches to your gun as soon as you find it, that would of been better then me having to choose between carrying a scope that zooms in or a potion that heals me, guess which one I went for. The same can be said for the different bombs and explosives, if I already have a slot for grenades, why not make me pick between swapping out my grenades for the mines I found or for the knife or for the homing bombs (which made no sense to me for having those specific items as carry items since it was just an upgrade to grenades). You can buy speed pills but again, that could of been a permanent upgrade. The same goes for the focus pills (they slow down time), just let me slow down time with the push of a button and have a bar that drains quickly while in use. 

I think the vending machines made sense and were a cool concept but sometimes the game wouldn't give you the vending machines you needed and would just spawn the same one 3 times in 1 floor. They could of at least made it that before you fight the boss, every vending machine was available to you in the room prior but instead you don't really get to prepare. So if you have 1 heart left and you are not close to a health vending machine, tough luck!

These are just the few problems I had with the game that I think, if ironed out, would make this a much more enjoyable and rewarding experience to play. Since the game is already difficult, these things just make it more frustrating because the consistency sometimes is not there. 

But Overall despite all the hardships, I did enjoy this game. I did want to come back to it and beat it. The game looks pleasing and it is also charming and challenging. 

The Gameplay was there and it was fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198269428786', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 152, 'playtime_forever': 366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1707261048}
review:
I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Thank you

author: {'steamid': '76561198060423492', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 875, 'last_played': 1696799808}
review:
Wow I did not expect the FPS and Rogue Like genres to mix together this nicely! This game is quite challenging, which makes it pretty fun doing "one more run" trying to reach to the end. You can however give yourself an easier time if you play slowly and use the bank often to deposit money and buy life insurance.

Love the visual style too, everything looks really striking and it's easy to make out where the enemies are (except those damn snakes hiding in the grass but that's definitely on purporse). Be sure to also pay attention to those sound cues! Most enemies have a unique sound effect when they spot you so you can tell what you're up against (and some can be heard even before you see them, so be extra careful!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198003010934', 'num_games_owned': 509, 'num_reviews': 311, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1695447184}
review: It's a fine little indie game. Not really my thing - I'm not super into rogue-likes - but it's pretty fun. The snakeworms ruin it pretty hard for me, to be honest. I almost only ever get killed by them and it makes most runs end in frustration. Other than that just a nice, simple shooter. Almost feels like a classic on-rails arcade shooter to me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083422579', 'num_games_owned': 936, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 882, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 882, 'last_played': 1693301006}
review:
[h1]장점[/h1]

- 80~90년대 스타일의 배경과 그래픽.

- 맵에 배치된 은행 기기들을 통해 돈을 미리 저장해두면 죽은 다음에 모든 걸 잃어도 은행에서 돈을 빼내서 쓸 수 있는 시스템 : 덕분에 계속 특정 스테이지에서 죽어도 꾸준히 저축해두다가 한 번에 인출해서 아이템들을 할인가로 사서 좀 더 쉽게 도전하는 플레이가 가능하다.

- 가볍고 빠른 게임의 템포. 총기는 오직 하나뿐이고 탄피를 주우면 그걸 다시 총알삼아 쏠 수 있다. 다른 총기나 복잡하게 신경써야 할 건 별로 없다.

[h1]단점[/h1]

- 결국 운에 대부분을 의존해야하는 게임 구조 : 로그라이크니까 이 점은 장르적 특성이라고 볼 수도 있지만, FPS임에도 플레이어의 에임이 좋다면 좀 더 빠르게 클리어하거나 덜 피격당할 순 있어도 극적인 상황 뒤집기는 어렵다. 운이 없다면 의료 자판기가 도저히 나오지를 않는다거나 나와도 포션을 팔지않아 돈 내고 3회 힐에 의존해야하는데, 아무리 천천히 가서 스테이지를 어찌저찌 민다 쳐도 보스에서는 그게 안 먹힌다.

- 모르면 맞아야지식 구성 : 일단은 약점이 있는 적은 그 부위의 색이 다르다던가 하는 식으로 약점을 표시해주긴 했는데, 게임 내에서 전혀 알려주지 않는다. 피격의 리스크가 현실적인 FPS 급은 아니더라도 어느정도 있는 편인데, 모르는 개체가 나오면 게임 템포도 빠른 탓에 맞을 수밖에 없다. 원거리 공격을 하는 적들은 명중률도 높아서 어지간하면 피격되기 마련.

- 비직관적인 아이템 설명 : 이게 뭐 하는 아이템인지 인벤토리를 열어서 살펴보지도 못한다. 오직 액티브 / 패시브 여부만 알려줄 뿐 설명도 없어 스팀 가이드를 켜서 이게 무슨 아이템인지 정확히 무슨 효과인지 알아봐야 한다.

- 오래 하다보면 아파지는 눈과 어긋난 디자인 : 특유의 그래픽 탓에 눈이 쉽게 피로해진다. 심지어 수풀사이에 위장색으로 숨어있는 벌레까지 있어서, 그 그래픽에서 벌레가 있는지도 제대로 확인하고 가야한다. 이동속도가 굉장히 빠른 걸 생각하면 오히려 느리게 가야한다는게 아이러니하다.

[h1]총평[/h1]

난이도가 꽤 있는 로그라이크 FPS 게임. 심지어는 자판기들마저도 모조리 운이라 운이 없다면 제대로 뭘 해보기도 전에 끝나지만, 운이 좋다면 어찌어찌 보스까지는 갈 수 있다. 막상 그 보스는 패턴도 다양하지 않고 터렛과 잡몹 도배에 일차원적인 폭탄던지기뿐인건 아쉬운 부분. 그럭저럭 시간 때우기로 할 수는 있어도, 그 이상의 의미는 없을 것 같다. 75% 할인 때 사면 적당할 것 같은 가격.

[b]6  / 10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198799030806', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1694494278}
review:
Never played a 3D rouge-like before this. Very cool! Gameplay and graphics are very reminiscent of SUPERHOT minus the whole "time stopping when you're still" thing and the atmosphere and aesthetics reminds me of Hotline Miami.

I got this on sale for ~A$3 and gotta say that's an absolute steal. It's absolutely worth the A$15 if you're into rouge-likes (I think).

author: {'steamid': '76561197999499904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1689092941}
review: This game absolutely needs a warning for flashing lights, or a way to turn them off. It's a nightmare trying to play this game when you're sensitive to these kinds of visuals. Also, some of the enemies are just completely hidden in the environments and kill you out of nowhere. On top of that, none of the items you can buy tell you what they do. There's just no fun in this game, in my opinion

review: An ok fast-paced shooter that's really hard. It plays best when you're trying to go as fast as possible, its main flaw is that the game never encourages you to do that. You're left to figure out the "right way" to play the game on your own, and that took me a couple years of on-and-off play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122709232', 'num_games_owned': 714, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1661424571}
review: Just an...intensely boring experience? With all the rave reviews I thought there would be something more, so maybe that's on me, but it's just an incredibly simple roguelike FPS. The environments are incredibly bland (even taking into account the polygon count), the enemies are fine, the gameplay is just intensely repetitive. I could list a dozen roguelikes or retro shooters that I'd rather be playing than this. Sure, the limited ammo is a fun gimmick, but a gimmick isn't going to keep me entertained for long if nothing is done with it. That's all this game is: a gimmick.

review: The game's aesthetic reminds me of the taste of monster ultra rosa, very y2k but in a tasteful not over the top kinda way. It plays like a good rougelike with a retro feel but also packing modern quality of life and innovation. There is also a progression system with upgrades, equipment and that sorta stuff. Despite you getting more powerful, it never fails to be challenging at every moment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052028033', 'num_games_owned': 894, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1681686396}
review:
Heavy Bullets is pretty much a single gimmick game. You run, you shoot enemies, they die in one hit (although some of them might be tricky to hit), bullets you shot drop and can be picked up, and have to be picked up, otherwise you find yourself out of bullets.

There are two issues with that. First, it limits your approaches to the game. You will find yourself waiting for enemy to come closer before you kill them, because you always want bullets to drop nearby. This is also enforced by the fact that you virtually can't fight multiple enemies at once - all enemies are fast, and if something charges at you - you HAVE to kill it, otherwise you are going to be dead in a seconds. So you just lure them one by one, standing around a corner. Fun!

Another issue is that game claims to have roguelike elements, but the only roguelike thing game does is random levels. You virtually get no tools to add variety to how you do things. Like, you get bombs and rockets that help you fight enemies, but use 1-3 of those - and they are gone. There are also passive items, but there are very few, and you can only hold two at times (which also makes finding new stuff less exciting, knowing you have to leave something behind). The only way your character improves is getting more bullets, more health, and pickup radius. This obviously doesn't play well into having fun in continuous restarts of the game (which will be plenty, because you die FAST).

So, no, it is not worth its price. If you look into action based roguelikes - look no further than Risk of Rain 2. If you want FPS roguelike - even Tower of Guns would probably be better than this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080196486', 'num_games_owned': 1031, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 712, 'last_played': 1681146174}
review:
Terri Vellmann and Doseone, the developers of “Heavy Bullets”, have since gone on to carve out their own niche, and make their own small impact onto the indie scene, with 2020’s “Disc Room” and 2021’s “Sludge Life”, which both currently sit at around 500 reviews each, both with a cushy score of “Overwhelmingly Positive” here on Steam. Back in 2014, however, they created this tiny little action roguelite, centered around ammunition scarcity, and a peculiar, minimalist aesthetic.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
[h2]PROS[/h2]
+ Interesting gimmick (sixshooter: you have to reload each bullet separately by mashing “R”, though you can get reload upgrades, to be able to reload more bullets at the same time
+ Very skillful, accuracy-based gameplay (in theory)
+ Interesting enemy ideas
+ Quite pleasant color palette, similar to Hyper Light Drifter

[h2]Neutral[/h2]
-) no item descriptions
-) few room and item variants
-) only two bosses (always the same)
→ less variety, but easier to learn

[h2]CONS[/h2]
- Weird hitboxes (especially on the turrets)
- Turrets and exploding enemies are way harder than any other enemy (uneven difficulty distribution); some enemies even blend into the background 
- Bad knife hitbox
- Small, weird bugs: [list]
[*] Random prompt to pick something up, that wasn’t there
[*] Shielding Enemies (Crawlers) sometimes shield after the bullet should’ve already stuck them, but it still deflects off of them (not good in a game with highly precious ammo counts)
[*] An enemy spawned right in front of me, as I entered a new floor once. Your screen is black for some time after you’re actually spawned in, and you start each floor staring at the ceiling, so it got two hits off on me.
[*] Momentary lag after killing an enemy sometimes (on a beefy rig!), even occurs sometimes while just shooting, and is particularly bad with [spoiler]flying turrets and the final boss[/spoiler]
[/list]
- Sparse graphical variety throughout the whole game (gets a little darker, and has slightly more tech and machinery haphazardly placed around the place towards the tail end of the experience, that’s it)
- Small amount of items
- Ludicrous prices at some shops, without money dropped from enemies scaling too much, if at all; sometimes a type of shop just straight up doesn’t appear for a while.
- The Random enemy spawns make for very inconsistent difficulty, even though the rooms are relatively the same
- Some useless/badly explained upgrades and items = like the magnet upgrades, which I see no reason for buying
- The bosses are bad. The first one suffers from the same hitbox issues as the turrets, and the second one is just enemy spam, that can, in my opinion, only be countered with HP upgrades and having a golden potion (best healing item in the game) on hand
- Janky stealth in tall grass
- Annoying enemy that hides in grass, and can sometimes poison you, basically putting you on death’s door a lot of the time, through one mistake (Snakeworm). Though, like Minecraft poison, it can only ever get you to half a heart, never kill you outright.
- Runs outstay their welcome; my winning run of the game was 44 minutes long

[h1]Longer Review[/h1]
[h2]Story[/h2]
The game takes place inside of a simulation. A little screen during the game’s startup sequence reveals a conversation, between two unidentified individuals working for a company named “Highrise Hunting Grounds”, on an emergency phone line together, who discuss sending the “janitor” over, to investigate a mysterious bug in the system mainframe, at level 8, which is “attacking customers”. They both explain how they’ll just advertise to anyone, that if they manage to do it, they get 5000$. They also, however, mention a high risk of death (one which they most likely obfuscate from the actual volunteers).
This tiny, and only, story excerpt sets up everything you need to know about what is occurring, particularly well. Even setting up a little intrigue, to make the player want to see what is causing the bug in the end.

[h2]Music And Sound Design[/h2]
The music is interesting, and discordant. An earlier, dare I say, more barebones effort by Doseone, who was responsible for music and SFX, and would later go on, two years after Heavy Bullets, to make the great soundtrack to Enter The Gungeon. Unfortunately the game only has two audio options, that you may tune in the menu: “Global Volume” and “Music Volume”, making it so that at any of the global volumes, from 1-10, the music is drowned out by the SFX. The music will also constantly, and dizzyingly stop, only to restart again, moments later. The music is alright on its own, its marriage with the gameplay, visuals and the context of the whole rest of the soundscape leaves a lot to be desired. The SFX themselves were simple and serviceable – no complaints there.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
You are thrust, immediately after pressing “New Game” and seeing or skipping the little story chatbox crawl, into the world of the “Highrise Hunting Grounds” simulation, armed with a sixshooter. The chambers of this revolver each have to be reloaded individually, and you only start with six bullets, which you have to pick up after each shot fired. You better make 'em count! You can acquire more bullets later, either by finding them on green item/pickup pedestals strewn about the maze-like world, or by buying them from vending machines. 
This is where the usual Roguelite mechanic, of carrying things over between runs, emerges. The game has a money and banking system. You will find shops in the form of vending machines everywhere, and often – but, alongside them, you may also find banks. Here, you can deposit or withdraw money, to buy things from the vending machines; most of which are very expensive, so you might get a leg up with that extra inheritance from the poor sod, who tried before you!
While this mechanic is quite interesting, and a fun, if simple variation on the “inheritance” mechanics of some other roguelites (Rogue Legacy comes to mind), it’s not quite enough to salvage the game for me. For while the experience is both frenetic and stimulating, it has also got a lot of monotony, through its lack of new visual stimuli or more interesting gameplay mechanics, past the first “huh, interesting banking system” and “huh, interesting weapon”. The upgrades and items are boring, and apart from increasing max health (which you’ll usually find yourself too short on cash for), or Reload upgrades, will not really provide you with much value, certainly nothing “spicy”.
“Nothing spicy” also goes for the game’s secrets, marked by tiny “X”s on the walls, similar to The Binding of Isaac’s tinted rocks. One, which I found, on my last run of the game featured the message “All the rocks here look the same”, which sums it up pretty perfectly for me: the game’s developers can make on-the-nose jest about their game’s shortcomings, but never, in the past 9 years, took the time to address them.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
“Nothing spicy” could actually be my tagline for Heavy Bullets: from the janky enemies of highly variable difficulty, to the often frustrating, random enemy placement and other things, which make your runs contingent, to some extent, on RNG; to the same drab environments making me feel like I’m going insane at times, the enjoyment of Heavy Bullets, to me, is very finite. The game’s overall jankyness (which is inexcusable in places) holds it back from me recommending it in 2023.
I’m not surprised, as it is the developer’s first major effort, and was pretty solid for 2014, a time when modern Indie game development was still learning how to crawl for the most part, but it couldn’t keep my attention. Not now, having revisited it on a whim, nor last time, when I played it for a few hours in 2015.

Either way, despite all the flaws:
[h3]Thank You To Terri Vellmann And Doseone For Sharing Their Lovingly And Passionately Crafted Entertainment With Me, And Special Thanks To Devolver Digital For Publishing It![/h3]

review:
mmmm not that much to talk about it here: a rogue like shooter based on ''spotting'' the enemy and to plan ahead, which could interesting if combined with its minimalistic game design, with almost ''synth'' graphics and a straightforward story... Buuuuuuut it is way too miniminalistic to actually be entertaining for more than 2 minutes, failing its ''rogue like'' nature.
So, nope. I don't get how much rating this game got but for me, it's a no (at least, not for the original price).

author: {'steamid': '76561199439380047', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1674144438}
review:
[h1]Тяжелые пули[/h1]
[i]Мой один из любимых жанров игр, это "roguelike", почему же да думаю тут многим нравиться этот жанр своим рандомом, и эта игра не хуже, да есть свои нюансы которые режут глаза, но рогалик да и хардкорный ещё), прошёл спустя 4 часа. А чтобы её пройти нужно чуть собраться и включить в некоторых моментах стелс режим)). Помогу тем кто будет играть, первый босс самый сложный, а второй то-есть финальный самый простой. [/i]
[hr][/hr]
[h1]Плюсы[/h1]
⚜️Саундтрек
⚜️Так как это рогалик, тут очень хороший рандомайзер локаций и т.д.
[hr][/hr]
[h1]Минусы[/h1]
🛑Графика уж очень режет глаза, слишком простая.
🛑Управление, хоть и наиграл 4 часа но иногда чисто машинально, жмёшь пробел или шифт, чтобы прыгнуть или убежать, а по итогу вы бросаете гранату или используете предмет из ивентаря.
[hr][/hr]
[h1]Итоги[/h1]
[b]Так как я любитель этого жанра, буду оценивать эту игру серьезно, проанализировав всё написанное сверху я понял что игра среднячок, проиграв в многие рогалики могу выставить вердикт.[/b]
[h1]Моя оценка 6/10[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561199023562025', 'num_games_owned': 257, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1386, 'last_played': 1702596966}
review:
One hell of a roguelike.  Featuring a number of built in systems to allow the player to snowball by doing a few consecutive runs, Heavy Bullets is very addictive. For a simple FPS with bare-bones roguelike mechanics, there's a large level of depth and nuance in the moment to moment gameplay. You'll never get a new  gun or a damage upgrade, but you can upgrade your revolver to reload all six cartridges at once. 

The difficulty will keep you coming back to give one more shot at clawing your way down to the 8th floor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000582568', 'num_games_owned': 1975, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1702048999}
review:
Wenn man an Ego-Shooter denkt, denkt man oft an bombastische Grafiken, komplexe Geschichten und schnelle Action. "Heavy Bullets" von Terri Vellmann und Devolver Digital bricht mit diesen Konventionen und präsentiert sich als ein minimalistischer Shooter, der auf einzigartige Weise fesselt. In dieser Review tauchen wir in die Welt von "Heavy Bullets" ein und erkunden, warum dieses Spiel ein Meisterwerk der Einfachheit ist.

[b]Grafik und Präsentation:[/b]
"Heavy Bullets" unterscheidet sich deutlich von anderen Shootern durch sein minimalistisches Design. Die Spielwelt besteht aus schlichten geometrischen Formen und lebendigen Farben. Dieses minimalistische Design zieht den Spieler in seinen Bann und schafft eine unmittelbare Verbindung zur Spielwelt. Die klaren Linien und leuchtenden Farben tragen zur Übersichtlichkeit bei und fügen sich nahtlos in das Gesamtbild ein.

[b]Sound und Musik:[/b]
Der Soundtrack von "Heavy Bullets" ist ebenso minimalistisch wie das Design des Spiels. Die elektronischen Klänge und subtilen Beats erzeugen eine surreale Atmosphäre, die die Spieler in ihren Bann zieht. Die Soundeffekte sind präzise und dienen dazu, die Spieler in die Welt des Spiels zu versetzen.

[b]Spielmechanik:[/b]
Das herausragende Merkmal von "Heavy Bullets" ist sein einzigartiges Waffen- und Munitionssystem. Der Spieler beginnt mit einer begrenzten Anzahl von Kugeln, die nach jedem Schuss manuell aufgesammelt werden müssen. Dies schafft eine ständige Spannung und erfordert taktisches Denken. Das Spiel zwingt den Spieler, seine Ressourcen klug zu verwalten und sorgt so für eine intensive Spielerfahrung.

Die prozedural generierten Level von "Heavy Bullets" bedeuten, dass keine zwei Durchläufe gleich sind. Dies fördert die Erkundung und Experimentierfreude, da der Spieler nie genau weiß, was ihn erwartet.

[b]Geschichte und Atmosphäre:[/b]
Die Handlung von "Heavy Bullets" ist minimal und dient hauptsächlich als Rahmen für das Gameplay. Die Atmosphäre des Spiels ist jedoch fesselnd. Die ständige Bedrohung durch feindliche Kreaturen, das begrenzte Inventar und die unberechenbaren Level sorgen für anhaltende Spannung.

[b]Fazit:[/b]
"Heavy Bullets" ist ein eindrucksvoller Beweis dafür, dass weniger manchmal mehr sein kann. Das Spiel präsentiert ein minimalistisches Design, das den Spieler in seinen Bann zieht, und ein einzigartiges Munitionssystem, das für intensive Spannung sorgt. Obwohl die Geschichte und die Grafik schlicht gehalten sind, überzeugt das Spiel durch sein unkonventionelles Gameplay und seine fesselnde Atmosphäre. Für Spieler, die nach einer einzigartigen Shooter-Erfahrung suchen, ist "Heavy Bullets" eine lohnenswerte Entdeckung und ein Beweis dafür, dass Simplizität und Einfachheit oft die tiefgreifendsten Erlebnisse schaffen können.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064346794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1672335518}
review:
Reached last level, few rooms before final boss.
Not a roguelike - after death you get no upgrades, you can only carry over some of your money to buy upgrades during next run, which are: max health, max ammo, magnet range, consumables like healing potion or few-seconds slow motion.
So the game is mostly about carefully exploring rooms trying to get as little damage as possible.
Seems to have no replay value, no permanent upgrades, so it will be somewhat fun for 2-5 hours, until you beat the game or get tired of trying.
Most monsters die from one hit, health gets costly to restore, you will lose most health either to snakes ambushing in the bushes or random weakling attacking you while you run around turret aiming for it's weakspot - it can't hit you while you are moving. So any run itself is not much fun.
Adding permanent upgrades like max health, max ammo or discount % per 1000 gold accumulated/spent could really make game enjoyable

author: {'steamid': '76561198275299055', 'num_games_owned': 33, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1665542594}
review: Un juego con una estética visual impresionante, un soundtrack que parece tener conciencia propia, una temática synthwave innovadora, liviano, sencillo, pero sobre todo, entretenido, es un juego en el cual debes prestarle mucha atencion a tu medio ambiente si no quieres ser devorado por una fauna peligrosa e interesante, la rapidez, accion, livianez y sobre todo accesibilidad del juego, lo hacen un FPS de mazmorras increíble mediante el recorrido a través de estructuras laberínticas en donde cada decision cuenta y cada bala cuesta al punto de que solo una podria salvarte la vida, es un juego muy infravalorado y sinceramente merece una oportunidad, tiene su dificultad y es perfecto para pasar el rato, los unicos desperfectos son el que no posea un modo online y falta de disponibilidad en idioma español, solo ingles y el portugues fue añadido unicamente porque uno de sus desarrolladores, que es brasileño, así lo decidió , pese a eso, es un excelente juego y lo recomiendo, AMPLIAMENTE.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043974607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1662651445}
review:
Un petit roguelike FPS rigolo, avec un gimmick sympa : on a peu de balles, il faut les récupérer après les avoir tirées. Rien que pour ça le jeu mérite d'être essayé, c'est franchement marrant, mais pour pas cher.
Après, la structure roguelike fatigue un peu, impose un tour par un wiki (alors que l'interface aurait très bien pu donner les caracs de base des items) et les runs sont trop longs et peu rewardings pour donner envie de tryhard. Et apparemment ça fait aussi parler ton brain like Jeanclod Vandamme.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984228901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 281, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1656810065}
review:
Heavy Bullets is the perfect "before work" game. No massive progression system, no classes or skills, no long drawn out dialogues, what you see in the trailer is exactly what you will play. That may sound boring, but Heavy Bullets gave me that "one more run" vibe, death is quick but death is almost always your fault. nearly all enemies are killed in one shot at their weak spots, the revolver is the only gun in the game but you do have explosives like grenades and missiles. Items are found or bought from vending machines, but from experience, nearly every item and explosive is really bad and the main item i would keep on me were potions or slow-mo pills.

The game can be beat on the first try if you get very lucky or play cautiously, and because there's no real progression system, aside from the banks you can store money and items or buy items that let you bring some of that coin to your next run, every run starts fresh. My only real complaint about the game is the full price and content. $10 is kinda steep in my opinion, but i guess in 2014 this type of game didn't have alot of competition like it does now with 100's of fantastic roguelikes. Its a one off honestly, i have no desire to replay it after finishing, but i enjoyed my time even if it was short. On sale for $2, 100% a buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198274151104', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 205, 'playtime_forever': 2804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2804, 'last_played': 1652706144}
review:
[hr][/hr]
[table]
[tr]
[th][b]MY RATING:[/b][/th]
[th][b] 🌟 🌟 🌟 🌟 🌟 🌟 🌟 ✘ ✘ ✘ [/b][/th]
[th][b]7 / 10[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[/table]

I wasn't quite sure if I should write a review for the almost 8 year old game or not. Then I thought why not. It's not a bad game, so...

[b]But before we start:[/b]

Neon mode: 🔲 off ✅ on
LSD mode:⠀  🔲 off ✅ on

The mainframe in the company Highrise has gotten out of control, but unfortunately it is not around the corner, but on the eighth basement floor. So there is a small path ahead of us that we will tackle with a six-shot pistol. But there's a little catch. Ammo costs money and cannot be bought everywhere. But the fired ammunition can be picked up again so you don't really have to worry at first because it only gets a little tighter on the fifth floor.

I found the low-poly landscape with the, let's just call it quite daring visual style that resembles a neon LSD trip, took some getting used to at first. But then it went quite quickly until the eyes got used to it and it also gets a bit darker or redder with later levels. I didn't take screenshots this time because I think that a still picture isn't meaningful in this case and it gives the impression that it's a lifeless game. I find what is shown on the store page is meaningful enough.

I would say that [b]the gameplay is comparable to a shooter in the classic sense[/b]. Most opponents can be killed with a well-aimed shot, but there are also defense towers where you should hit the energy tank and also opponents who can only be done with a well-aimed shot in their backside. A bit of dancing skill, especially if you're wearing the right high heels, isn't necessarily a bad thing. And you'll find out exactly what the heels are all about in the game, or you can just take a look at the achievements for the game.

As I see it or understand it, [b]the levels are randomly generated[/b]. This means that if you die and have to start over, the path to the exit and also the opponent (position) will change and the gameplay will vary greatly. And even if Heavy Bullets is a fairly fast game, you should proceed carefully because you can very often encounter snakeworms that hide in bushes of the same color and are not only harmful but also have the property of poisoning the player. So always pay attention to the ground!

As already mentioned, you can buy additional ammunition. But that's not all. Everywhere there are vending machines where you can buy other weapons or medicines in addition to ammunition. If you buy a backpack, you get another slot and can carry another item with you. At ATMs you can also deposit the money that each defeated opponent leaves behind as booty, so to speak, into your account or buy “your last will”. This "last will" has the advantage that it is not only available in the current game, but also after death. This means that the inventory and upgrades are inherited. Another alternative is life insurance, which you can also buy. Unlike the last will, this does not inherit the inventory, but in the event of death, it pays a portion of the coins captured up to that point to your account. Furthermore, there are some (hidden) bonus items in the levels. It is therefore worth taking a close look all the more.

I recommend you, at least those who are looking for it or value it, to [b]take a closer look at the achievements before you start playing.[/b]

Technically I had no problems with Heavy Bullets.

[hr][/hr]
[b]MY PROS AND CONS:[/b]

✅ brightly colored
✅ fast shooter action
✅ Randomly generated levels

❌ small scope
❌ few different opponents

[hr][/hr][b] PLAYED WITH: ⌨️ 🖱 🎧 [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198054891702', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1653234173}
review:
I could say many good things about Heavy Bullets, but one that stands out the most is its sound design. 

You'll spend most of your playtime in absolute silence (i.e. without any soundtracks playing in the background), which makes every sound effect very clear and easily recognizable. Using the sounds, you will be able to tell that there's an enemy nearby, what type is it, when is it safe to leave your cover and also find pickups. The latter are jumping around and making noises, which works very well with the core mechanic of picking up the bullets you fired.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044270955', 'num_games_owned': 442, 'num_reviews': 450, 'playtime_forever': 7338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7338, 'last_played': 1645165594}
review:
[h1] *Clears Throat Prepping for bad Russian Accent*[/h1]
A dark and vyaporwave cyave
Has never felt so glreat
An empty magnyum only shows what's left ienside
Lost in this technicolour meaze
Explossive Metafase
The neon beckons me beyond this demonic light

No longer I pre-tend
This ladder I dyescend
Will lead me anywherre except the games unflashy end
My hearts are low by this time
The gun still in my line of sight
Too late to turn back, only Imp's fate left to decide

HYEAVY BOOLETS
Settling the achievements
HYEAVY BOOLETS
I don't deserve this treatment

Back at the start agyain
I'm bleeding from my abdomyen
A broken casing only shows a gold potiyan
Running in boots thyat stomp on snakes
Somewhere probably out in spyace
A stinging trophy of the byattles I've lost

No longer byad at aiming
No choices left remaining
I'll 100% this game in time
My steam library paralyzed
Against the rising tide
Of games that I've bought but aren't worth my life

[h1] WTF was that?[/h1]

Hyeavy Boolets is a game where you play as John Night Runner, a man on a mission tasked with ridding an alien species from a maze like labyrinth space-station. The alien has changed most of the creatures in this natural habitat into genuinely terrifying creatures. The game proves that you don't need high end graphics to make a game scary, you don't even need to make horror the main aspect of the game. Equipped with 6 bullets, and 3 bombs, John Night Runner must make use of limited resources to fight against this horde of mind controlled mutated animals, and automated defenses made solely to kill anyone not recognized. Such as John Night Runner. Why didn't you get equipped with something to turn over the defenses? The aliens must be blocking the signals. That's  the only explainable reason. And at the end of the game, through many technicoloured trials, you, like most Americans inact a hate crime, on what may be the only remaining individual of an alien species, effectively committing genocide with your best friend, Gun.

[h1] What's this Game have to Offer?[/h1]

A cool experience awaits you in this game, like most Devolver Digital games. Your gun is reloaded one bullet at a time, with you needing to pick up each bullet to get back your extremely limited ammo. As a shooter and a roguelike, you must get used to aiming very quickly and landing your shots, the reticle as such is tiny, and your boollets do not stray. Like most shooters, the game relies on sound. It's crucial for your survival to have your sound on. As every creature will first alert you by screaming at you, before turning into fucking nightmare fuel and rushing at you at high speeds, following you around corners and more. Like every small crawling child in every horror movie ever. You can spend money and sell items at vending machines, as well as blowing up vending machines, to boost your future runs, or help you on your current one. It's more of a true roguelike, you can save bullets, money, bombs, and a single item in between runs. But no permanent unlocks to protect your run from restarting to zero with the slightest mistake. A challenge that is quite awesome to run. And different runs grant some pretty easily completed achievements. The music good, obviously Doesone knows how to jam.

[h1]  TL;DR [/h1]

It's a rush of action, a bumb in the night, a jam to chill out too, and a challenge to be bested.
I recommend this game, and I think it fucking rocks.
I call this acid trip nightmare, crushed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100841051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1332, 'last_played': 1682716075}
review:
Heavy Bullets absolutely knocks it out of the park with its design. From brilliant music and visuals to engaging moment to moment gameplay, it's truly a unique experience for any fan of Roguelikes, First-Person Shooters, or just fun times in general. The combat feels tight and responsive, the enemies feel varied enough to present unique challenges while not being so complex that you need to think about something other than shooting them, and the items add a pleasant spice to gameplay to change up your runs a little each time.

There are only two major issues with this game that I can warn about. One is technical while the other is more gameplay related.

The first is the stutters the game suffers from. These really throw off your flow sometimes and can lead to you getting unfairly hit if you're not prepared to deal with them. However, they barely last a tenth of a second and aren't too intrusive.

The second is the scale of the game. With only eight floors that take about 2-5 minutes to clear each (once you get some experience under your belt), Heavy Bullets really leaves you hungering for more where it really can't provide. It seems like it has a ton of potential that it'll never reach, but this doesn't take away from the gameplay at all. It's still incredibly fun, if short and sweet.  

Lastly, strangely enough Heavy Bullets can be a very calming game. With all but two enemies requiring no more than a single bullet to kill, once you get more experienced, you can sit back, hunt monsters and chill out to the unique soundtrack as you glide from room to room.  
  
Heavy Bullets is an excellent game, and I highly recommend it to anyone checking the reviews to get a feel for if they should purchase it.

review:
Finally got around to beating this game like 5-6 years after I bought it.
It fun

author: {'steamid': '76561198010896861', 'num_games_owned': 821, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 599, 'last_played': 1642553517}
review:
Heavy bullets is a nice short rogue-like fps shoot'em up rpg game.

You have a revolver and must make it down to the mainframe to reset.
Along the way you have enemies that will kill you. You fight back to protect yourself and get money from their dead body to buy items and upgrades. You can also find secrets in the game for unique items.
There are a decent amount of enemy variety. with those that will chase you and others that are stationary.
The game only has 8 levels, 2 of which has a boss fight which makes it a nice a short game. Can be beaten in 25 minutes, but if you're exploring the level for items it will take at least an hour. The game floors randomize each time making your playthroughs different each time.

I quite enjoy the game, it's fun if sometimes getting cheap deaths.
The game rewards you for being methodical approach to exploring the floor, good planning and strategy, for reacting fast, having the right items, and most importantly accurate shooting. The game isn't overly difficult to get through once you got your game plan.
The items you find are either useful or not as useful as expected. I highly recommend that you look up a guide on what they do so you can make an informed decision on the items you pick up, because some items you pick up have negative consequences.
The gunplay and mechanics are fun and it's very important that you put the correct settings for you, because if you got the wrong sensitivity setup your aim will suffer greatly as you try to compensate for your aim.

Overall I like the game, and having it be a rogue-like game with each floor having a different layout with enemies scattered around gives it nice replay value. Could it be improved? It could have some more enemy variety types, more interesting items to play with, some more unique environment(but then again the theme of the game is you're trying to get to a mainframe in some weird corporate building, so it doesn't make sense to have weird hazards). I would really like to see them have co-op in the game where you and another player and try to get to the mainframe.

Would I recommend it? Yeah sure it's a good game that you can boot up once in a while to play to try and beat it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066496454', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 559, 'last_played': 1641498871}
review:
Another great game from power duo of Terri Vellmann and Doseone. If you played any of their games you know you should not miss one. 

Heavy Bullets is a minimalist approach to roguelite-FPS genre. It's fast, it's short, it's fun. There are enough items and variety so you wouldn't be bored till you beat the final boss. 

After finishing Heavy Bullets once there is not much incentive to come back for another playthrough, but 10 hours that you will spend completing the game will be fun as hell.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211503816', 'num_games_owned': 655, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 628, 'last_played': 1635292496}
review:
So I beat this game today and I gotta say I definitely enjoyed it! The gimmick of this game is that once you shoot your gun you have to go and collect the bullets for reuse because you'll only have a handful of bullets on you at a time. Although that is the advertised unique thing about the game, just about every item in this game is as short in supply as the bullets, making every item or tool you come across feel important. I really enjoyed this because it really made me plan my actions a few steps ahead and kept me on the edge of my seat as I was always one wrong decision away from a game over.

This game is not without it's flaws though. Much of the area of play is randomly generated and similar colors, making it very easy to get lost in the mazelike maps. Many of the special items available to the player also seem to make very little difference to the game. Many items had very situational, almost unhelpful effects like throwing bombs slightly further or simply just taking up space in your inventory and being meant to be sold for a decent price. On top of this, you can only have one active item on you at a time meaning that you can't even collect a good amount of these and grow in power and have a "god run" like so many other roguelike games will allow you to do. This is not inherently a negative, though, it just means that how good you do will be more dependent on how well you know the game's enemies and items.

Overall, I think the Heavy Bullets is a game with a fun core but some unnecessary or unhelpful elements that can serve to distract from the experience. I think it has a really cool art style and it's definitely not easy! If you like roguelikes or difficult games I'd check this one out :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197978943561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 1570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1570, 'last_played': 1624097419}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001113321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1179, 'last_played': 1644476164}
review:
I keep coming back to this game, because it is built around a great core mechanic. When you get in the zone and just nail 6 enemies with 6 shots, sweeping through and picking up all the bouncy pieces, it's really satisfying. It's focused, consistent, limited in scope and has a solid aesthetic to it - definitely worth your time.

Personally, I do have the stutter issue, had it on previous gaming rigs too, and it's not been so bad as to make the game unplayable. But it can definitely hurt your experience enough to make the game not worth it, so just watch for that.

What most hurts the game IMO is some inconsistencies with the general design. Turrets can shoot you either after a second or more of waking up, OR they can just instantly fire off a shot right between your eyes seemingly before they've even turned around. Your bombs barely move when you throw them and more often than not blow up in your face due to turret fire - for an item that's part of your basic gear, they do more harm than good, and go underutilized. Poison is a poorly implemented mechanic that seems to apply solely to a single enemy which is one of the most annoying and pervasive in the game. An enemy that already ambushes, damages and disorients you to begin with, which is quite enough. But the poison effect is rarely applied by their attacks, and it usually goes away after doing 1/2 heart of damage, making the effect too minor to justify wasting your only inventory slot on an antidote.

I just feel like some pieces of the game lack a certain level of polish and design effort that would take this game to the next level. There aren't a lot of moving parts here, and I really feel like it could use an extra layer or two of depth, and a bit more time in the oven to tighten things up. What's there is quite enjoyable, and I really do wish there was more to dig into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150318488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1624231096}
review:
This game meets all my requirements of a good game. I did not happen to scour a checklist while playing it. ;)

Sick rogue dungeon crawler. Probably my favourite and only video game I really play and have for a bit. I've yet to clear it (playing on an older mac+trackpad as of now:,,)) but I am progressing, since I am trying not to withdraw from the bank except for a fun run after I beat it. It's graphics don't get old for me, I love (and fucking HATE) the enemies, and the little things plus being able to kinda take your own pace, you can rush in or tactfully dart corners and take out creatures/turrets to make a room easier. I tend to veer on holding down "W" and spamming "R", but preparation to some extent is wise. Love it for breaking up time producing music, and also to escape on a boring night. Often boring nights seem more uncommon these days, until they crop up with a force. Gotta stay productive. Phenomenal game! I'll leave it at that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067884214', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1486017833}
review: Despite wanting to enjoy the game years ago and having high hopes, the game has unresolved stutter issues during gameplay, making it unplayable for a twitch skill rouge-like shooter. I gave the game several years to hopefully patch these issues but have read via the developers pinned thread on the discussion board for the game that attempts to solve the issue were unsuccessful and that they since abandoned the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198989051349', 'num_games_owned': 518, 'num_reviews': 487, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1621097227}
review:
FYI: My playtime isn't at all accurate because I pretty much only played this game in compatibility mode to stop the frame drops from occurring.

Right after beating High Hell and really liking it, I immediately played this game. The graphics were cool looking and the trailer made the gameplay look pretty fun but I have to say this game was pretty meh in my opinion. While the aforementioned graphics are great and the soundtrack is also pretty good, the core gameplay isn't very fun and this game just feels a little too punishing for it's own good. While I did sink something like 15 hours or something into this game, I can't say that they were super enjoyable. I still think that the devs who made this are great and I especially loved Disc Room and Minit but I think this game just kinda misses the mark for me and thats coming from a fan of both Roguelikes and First-Person Shooters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069101936', 'num_games_owned': 308, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1619855455}
review:
Esse jogo me custou uma noite de sono perdida, e a troco de que ? Um pixel na tela em formato de troféu, dizendo "Winner - Beat the game" 
E é exatamente por esse motivo que esse fps rogue-like/dungeon crawler te fisga. Seus visuais são um agrado a mais para quem curte uma estética retrowave/low-poly (e pra quem não se importa em queimar a retina tbm, tudo brilha pra c𝓪cete).  
A agonia de querer tentar denovo e ir mais longe, de tentar chegar ao final e cumprir o desafio, rezar pra que venham itens melhores nessa tentativa (a maior parte dos itens é situacional), ou que tenham menos daquelas cobras escr𝖔tas escondidas na p𝖔rra dos arbustos etc.  
Quando você ver, fud𝓮u, já tá na 6a tentativa seguida, e o jogo cumpriu seu dever, fazendo você jogar do começo ao fim. (claro que vc tbm pode ter achado o jogo uma merd𝓪 depois da primeira rodada e ter c𝓪gado, mas ai é contigo mermo)

review: A fun little roguelike where you shoot stuff and pick your bullets back up. It's short but sweet, has decent replay value considering its length (my first winning run took me roughly 50 minutes). Good and snappy shooting mechanics and a simple but beautiful art style lend this game a lot of charm. I wish it were longer and had more depth, but for $5-10 CDN it's well worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145321174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 942, 'last_played': 1613279382}
review:
[h1]HEAVY[/h1]

[b] Gamplay: [/b]
Pretty standard stuff for an FPS, you aim the mouse and click to shoot, the main difference being the reload mechanics and different items to help you, and hurt you, alongside a couple of enemies that behave very differently from one another. 
As the game title suggests, the bullets you pew pew are so heavy you can reuse them on the one-hit enemies. There are also upgrade mechanics to help you reload, max out your health, carry more items and pick-up coins and bullets.  
The variation on enemies is little, but very effective and fun. Each have their own sounds, look and attack, so you can quickly react to each enemy type once you get fast and accurate with your shots (although sometimes, the enemies spotted me through the walls and got in a few cheap shots, but for most of the time I could react before the damage).
The rooms are procedurally generated, which adds to the replay value of the shooty shoot game.
The difficulty feels nice and achievable to master since it is so easy to pick up, more so if you are experienced with the genre.

[b] Art-Style: [/b]
I love the low-poly style in every asset and the use of a cold palette for the environments, enemies and most of the items is very well implemented. 
I usually don't like gradients, but this game does them really well and I didn't get tired of the colors and rooms and enemies. 
The sounds and quick bites of music are also really satisfying; Don't how to describe them but feel very bit-crushed and slowed down. It sounds pretty neat.

[b] Story & Characters: [/b]
Not a whole lot here. I think you are a janitor that took up the task of rebooting an infected system, which combine really well with the sounds and colors. 
There are only two characters that chat at the beginning and end of the game, who gave me the vibe of bumbling, clueless guys, just like me!

[b] Achievements: [/b]
Most of these are fun in concept, but they are almost all based on RNG. You must hug the wall to discover secret items that my not alway appear in different runs, so you mostly rely in luck rather than skill to 100% the game.
Patience is a must if you want all the achievements, but there aren't a lot of them so that's cool.
OH! There is also a very cool achievement to "speedrun" the game in 25 minutes, meaning you must do all 8 rooms in 4 minutes (approximately), which makes it very satisfying when you go below that quarter! That's a pretty cool skill cap.

[b] TL;DR [/b]
Easy to pick-up and satisfying to master. Nice colors and quick replay value!
But me no likey RNG on achievements >: (

author: {'steamid': '76561198343069362', 'num_games_owned': 35, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1621364624}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040088790', 'num_games_owned': 1297, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 878, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1707533542}
review: Honestly this is one of my favorite rougelikes, as it's fun, faced paced, and it pushes you focus on your skill more than remembering what a massive list of items do (don't get me wrong, I love games with loads of items too, but it's nice to have a simpler option). There are items and upgrades, but the gameplay stays consistent for the most part and anything that changes how the game plays can be dropped (hold E or whatever key you have set to open doors and pick up items) or sold, so there's no commitment. I will say, if you NEED a game to have a story, then this won't be for you as there's no story other than explanation of whats happening and your role in the situation. This game may seem extremely difficult at first, but I feel it just takes some time getting used to and practice. For the longest time I struggled to get past the halfway point, but it was like the moment I had put 10 hours into it, it was like my third eye opened and I went full god mode, beating the game two runs in a row. Basically what I'm trying to say is that if you feel that this game is too difficult for you at first, don't give up! It honestly just takes patience with getting in practice and being able to keep your cool in difficult situations. I would [i] HIGHLY [/i] recommend buying/using the focus pills for boss fights (maybe get 2 or 3), as they make it a lot easier to dodge when you're getting rushed with attacks and they let you line up your shots easier.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166771313', 'num_games_owned': 1351, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 876, 'last_played': 1611420113}
review:
Its a good Roguelike game with a unique shift where its a FPS game that your bullets are limited and you have to pick them up after shooting and reload each bullet at a time unless you get upgrades. The art style is pretty cool with a popping neon look although one of graphics options that makes the came look so blurry or saturated its pleasant to look at that it hurt my eyes almost.

I will say this game needs more content to help make it feel like every playthrough is different that you can have a tiny spreadsheet with item in the game while compared to Binding of Isaac, Dead Cells, and Gungeon there is a lot of different items that can change the outcome of every playthrough. Also finding the secret items was annoying that some walls have an "x" on them and others don't. Finally the final boss was disappointing compared to the first boss. The final boss is basically an onslaught of enemies with the boss is in a fixed position and slowly throws out explosions and its easy to exploit the fight the second you open the door.

Overall, still recommend it but don't expect to get as much replability compared to other Roguelikes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012489813', 'num_games_owned': 415, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1679691324}
review: Not exactly substantial, and weird, but both of these things were clearly intended. It's simple, and it provides a ton of unique situations and amazing aesthetics. Certain mechanics here are rarely used anywhere else, like hard to see enemies and extreme ammo conservation importance, both of which are annoying but highly rewarding. Also, the gunplay feels really substantial and satisfying, which it has to in a game where shooting is all you do and you only get to do it so often. For how cheap it is, if you like roguelites or PvM shooters, just get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994526477', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1566678157}
review: A fun roguelike with several key mechanics to master. Not too simple, not too complex, a good balance. The challenge continues to ramp up as you go. The turrets are particularly annoying and I could definitely do without the fast traveling projectiles, as 9/10 times I am dying from them instead of something more interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110058844', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1625469938}
review: Loads of fun; game is punishing, but coming back to start a new run is always a blast. Being able to put your money into a bank and even saving an item for the next run is a nice touch as well. There is indeed a learning curve with learning monster behavior, but it's rewarding to get through areas you previously had a hard time with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025851638', 'num_games_owned': 263, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2066, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1563, 'last_played': 1706983248}
review:
This is a lovely little game that can really hit the spot if you're in the mood for something arcade-like.

HB is easy to dip into and out of, but I'm reluctant to describe it as casual: you're a janitor tasked with traversing a vaporwavesque safari cyberscape  populated by feisty critters and indiscriminate security turrets. Survival here requires speed, accuracy, and more than a little corner-peeking. Bullets are scarce, but retrievable and reusable. Everything dies in one hit, but consecutive misses are costly. 

HB's light narrative serves as a gentle capitalist critique, and this theme undergirds the game's second novelty:  a banking system in which cash deposited in one run can be withdrawn in a subsequent one postmortem. Money can be exchanged for precious bullets, additional lives and all manner of other equipment, and it's hard to beat the game (I've never done it) without a little starting wealth. Adjacent mechanics include a 'last will' and a life insurance system. 

Whilst enemies are numerous, varied and quick off the mark, they are all a little stupid. This is a  conscious design decision that makes sense for the game, but it also invites tedious strategies like backpedalling and waiting for a cluster of dimwitted imps to charge you in a straight line one after another. It's not game-breaking, but it doesn't really fit with the overall feel of the game, which generally rewards carefulness in conjunction with quick reflexes and accuracy. In any case the game is still hard: in 25 hours of play I've made it to the final boss a handful of times, and never lived to tell the tale.

I picked this game up for £1.75 in a sale, and it's definitely worth more than that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028854449', 'num_games_owned': 3161, 'num_reviews': 204, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1602486327}

author: {'steamid': '76561198123238864', 'num_games_owned': 451, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1572207780}
review:
Heavy bullet est un jeu particulier et intéressant. En fait, à chaque fois que vous tirez, vous devez aller chercher votre balle. Cette mécanique qui, de prime abord, semble assez simple au début devient très difficile à gérer plus on avance dans le jeu.
En effet, au début, les ennemis sont assez simples. Puis apparait les vers qui se faufilent dans la pelouse et qu’il vous faudra repérer, sinon jumpscrare garanti! Et si vous tirez dans la pelouse au hasard, vous devrez aller chercher les balles tirées. Puis viens les tourelles qui vous demanderont de tirer à un endroit bien précis et petit et là le jeu devient difficile, car si vous perdez toutes vos balles à tirer à côté, c’est fini!

Je n’ai pas réussi à me rendre très loin (il y a 10 niveaux randomisés par partie), mais pour ce que j’ai essayé, le jeu est assez bien. Des items à découvrir, de la réflexion, des réflexes et de la vigilance vous seront requis pour arriver à la fin. Très bon petit jeu à prendre pas cher.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042870845', 'num_games_owned': 543, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1530321953}
review: This game takes the familiar feeling of a roguelike, applies it to a first person shooter, and combines it into a sensory experience with great music. You have limited ammunition, only 6 bullets which must be recovered and manually reloaded each time they are fired. Enemies often have specific weak points, meaning you have to aim carefully. However, health is also a limited resource, so you’re forced to fire quickly and keep on the move. It’s a challenging experience that is definitely worth the low price tag.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038880470', 'num_games_owned': 361, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1593970344}
review:
[h1][b]★★★☆☆[/b][/h1]
If you bought the "Bundle for Racial Justice and Equality" on Itch, you should already have this game in possession, otherwise you should perhaps only [b]try[/b] this game out for yourself. 

The problem is that the developer left a graphical bug in it. It is not very noticable, but the framerate tends to drop for a mere second to pick up again immediately later. In other games, this might not be such a problem, but here it is. Some enemies in this game are very accurate with their aim and it reequires split-second reactions to dodge enemy fire, sometimes even just the enemy itself when it is charging you. A stutter can just kill your 30 min long run and bring you back to zero.

It is a real bummer for an otherwise cool and unique little game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037994664', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1210, 'last_played': 1594697481}
review: A fun little rouge-lite that'll keep you occupied for a good while.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994928050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1665746962}
review: Awesome little game this; in a nutshell it's a fps rogue like. The twist here is that your loops gets better by investing in previous rounds. You earn cash as you kill enemies and that cash can be banked during your run for use in the next run. It stays there till you use it. Devolvers use of colours might melt your brain, but funnily enough once your playing they create an easy, distinct style that still manages to up the panic when things get tense. Most of the time when you die, it will be your fault for not paying attention and in my opinion that elevates this title to the great rogue likes out there where you don't feel like your being (*#$#$ by the system. Everything works in this package and the more you jam it, the more addictive it becomes. I run a single session every other night and that's enough for me. This will continue to occupy a space on my hdd for some time to come.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060821109', 'num_games_owned': 1214, 'num_reviews': 226, 'playtime_forever': 765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1595208131}
review:
I got this game as part of the giant itch.io bundle and was enjoying it so much that I bought it on Steam too.

I'm generally not a huge fan of roguelikes, but this one does so many things well. It's a very simple start based on the great concept of having to go collect your fired bullets that then continues to build in complexity and strategy. The ability to bank the items you have collected is what really tipped the scales for me because even on a bad run I can build up my savings.

I have a huge library of games, but I can't stop thinking about firing Heavy Bullets up to do a couple more runs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970461293', 'num_games_owned': 1846, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1684269171}
review:
Great little game for a rin or two at a time.
The graphics might look too basic, but they work for the most part when in game.

Where this game shines is in the gameplay of demanding precision shooting, or you will quickly run out of bullets.
The randomization and permadeath of a roguelike lends itself well to this game. 

Many other roguelike shooters tend to get too long or luck of the run based. 
This has fairly short runs without you having to pray for a lot of drops to break the run, because you won't find it.

So in summary, you may like this if:
• You like short non-complex runs
• You like the idea of a precision FPS which has a good weight to the combat
• You can forgive the abstract art style

author: {'steamid': '76561198028055986', 'num_games_owned': 2405, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1593752919}
review:
I want to recommend Heavy Bullets. I love quick-play procedurally-generated rogue-likes/lites of almost every stripe. But there are some glaring issues that were never fixed and the developer silently vanished years ago.
[list]
[*]Micro-stutter: Frequently, the game just drops frames. This isn't a hardware issue; it was reported and acknowledge as far back as 2014, but was never fixed.
[*]Mouse-lock: After starting the game, the mouse will usually be unlocked from and out of sync with the camera, even in fullscreen, making targeting nearly impossible. This can be temporarily fixed by jacking around with FOV settings, but if you have the issue once it will return every time you start the game.
[*] AI clipping: Monsters appear to randomly gain the ability to clip through walls. It's unclear if this is actually frames dropping while an enemy is properly pathing, but the effect is the same - a monster not there a second ago is now spontaneously chewing on your face.
[/list]

The gameplay is solid and the visual and auditory minimalism add a great deal of charm, but these extremely obvious and often play-ruining bugs shouldn't have made it into the game. Six years after this game's release, there are plenty of options for neo-retro shooters; give your money to more polished and deserving games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013588423', 'num_games_owned': 1651, 'num_reviews': 219, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1701841552}
