author: {'steamid': '76561198041196019', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 627, 'last_played': 1698530741}
review:
I have a bit of a weak spot for Roguelikes, so when I saw this on sale, I had to check it out. Overall, I'm quite content with my decision to buy this game, although there's still a few things that really prevent me from fully enjoying it.

The pros:

1. One thing I really like about this game is that each enemy is unique and challenging in their own way. No one enemy feels too easy or hard too fight by themselves.

2. A problem that you sometimes see with games that have randomly generated levels is that they occassionally throw something nigh-unbeatable at you if you're unlucky. This game never does that. It gets harder as you go, but every death you have feels like its because of a mistake on your part, not on the game's part.

3. There is a small way that you can make future playthroughs easier. By storing money in the bank, you can have a large stockpile of cash to use in different playthroughs to make things easier. If you have a lot of trouble with this game, or if you run across some items that you want to buy but don't have enough money for, the bank has you covered. This really helps to take the edge off of this game's difficulty.

The cons:

Now that I've gotten the praise out of the way, let me address the one thing that "prevents me from fully enjoying this" as I said. During the beginning of the game, I noticed that it had the occasional stutter. By this, I mean that the game had a rare lag spike, in which everything would freeze for a second, before it would unfreeze, with me in a different spot. This was tolerable at first, but as the game progresses, it just gets worse.

Now, I should probably hedge this by saying that my computer is relatively low-end, but there aren't any options in the settings menu that make the game run any smoother for me. It should be said that Heavy Bullets is the kind of game that you do NOT want to have this kind of glitch in. By the seventh or eighth level, the stutter is so frequent that enemies that really should not be a problem become a nightmare. 

Oh yeah, and it makes it nearly impossible to beat the final boss, so have fun with that.

However, maybe this is just a problem that stems from my pc's general mediocrity, and if you have a better computer, it might work. Alledgedly, the dev is working on fixing this problem, but untill then, it really mars this game's performance.

With all this said, I still feel that it is overall an enjoyable experience. 7/10. I'll be willing to give it an 8.5/10 when and if the glitch is fixed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041857532', 'num_games_owned': 393, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1113, 'last_played': 1430803616}

author: {'steamid': '76561198029418461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1537127107}
review:
From its appearance to its mechanics, Heavy Bullets is not a complex game, but it is an elegant one. Tight corridors, blind corners, a limited eight-round chamber with retrievable bullets and fast, aggressive enemies and turrets. You usually learn lessons the hard way, but the smart design ensures you come across each problem one at a time; at the same time this design encourages careful, precise play over guns-blazing tactics. 10 hours in, I still don't know exactly what's going to be around each corner, but I do know that usually the best option is to keep my eyes and ears open, aim true, reload often, and shoot sparingly. The feeling of learning the game is highly rewarding.

Heavy Bullets punishes mistakes hard, but it does well to alleviate frustrations with some neat twists. The ability to save money across playthroughs ensures that each inevitable failed attempt doesn't have to feel like a waste. Keycards, vendors and items, each as randomised as the rest of the levels, encourage different tactics and using whatever's on hand to your advantage.

As of this date, there is one significant negative holding the game back. Many users including myself have experienced regular yet unpredictable microstutters during gameplay. In a game so tightly based around reaction time and precision, it can be positively maddening to drop hearts or even die from losing a much-needed split-second to the game's lag. While the game is by no means unplayable or unbeatable when played this way, several users have refused to play the game until this issue is resolved, and considering the type of game this is, I can't entirely blame them.

Other than that, once the initial hurdles are overcome you'll find the game isn't particularly long, and I don't see myself returning to it once I beat this final level at last. The graphics are simple but clear and easy to look at, and it looks smooth enough at 60fps, the aforementioned stutters notwithstanding. The audio is punchy and fitting with the style of the game, if not particularly catchy. As I've said, it's a simple game, but it delivers a tighter experience than so many games much more complex than it. Overall, a highly respectable diversion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971829250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1427246206}

review: Heavy Bullets, a permadeath FPS in which after every shot, you have to pick up your bullets to shoot them again. Your low count of bulets makes the game thrilling and difficult whilst still being very fun

author: {'steamid': '76561198025274522', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 381, 'playtime_at_review': 435, 'last_played': 1711649398}
review:
I realized, I play Heavy Bullets in the same way as I play Receiver. They are as alike as they are different. You have a gun, you have bullets. You load your gun one bullet at a time. You shoot turrets that stand still and take potshots at you, or you shoot things that rush you. Both are rules-lite, systems-lite. I keep coming back to both of them.

However, Heavy Bullets is bright, and simple, and teeming with life, where Receiver is monotone in color, byzantine in keybindings, and thematically devoid of life. Heavy Bullets has an end but not much story. Receiver has little more than it's story, but there isn't really an end to the gameplay. 

And I love them both for all of those reasons. 

I have a feeling Receiver is the game I'll return to in the long run, not strictly the better game, but there it is.

But Heavy Bullets: "A+++ wuld shoot again!!!!"

author: {'steamid': '76561197995673722', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1308, 'last_played': 1431009863}
review:
With the "dearth" of First Person Shooters available on the market Heavy Bullets provides a fresh example that you don't need overly complex systems in place to be fun. In a move completely opposite to Borderlands billions of guns, Heavy Bullets has one, your trusty 6 shot revolver. Each time you fire a shot, you must then recover that bullet in order to be able to reload it and fire it again unless you are carrying more than just the 6 bullets your start each run with. This creates some interesting situations where you'll be aiming across the room and weighing up whether you're confident of hitting your target; missing may mean having to run across the room with no way of attacking enemies. 

Heavy Bullets features an ever familiar roguelike formula of randomized dungeons as you work your way through 8 levels with increasing varied enemies; at the end of levels 4 and 8 you will fight a fixed boss. Each enemy requires a different strategy in order to tackle them effectively but all drop when hit with one bullet to their weak spot (The only exceptions being the bosses and one enemy). Enemies are varied enough but if you take a methodical pace you can deal with them fairly easily, as long as you're accurate with your shots. I would personally recommend using keyboard and mouse for this game, I tried using a wired Xbox 360 controller but could never find a setting I was truly happy with. 

In addition to your gun there are a number of items in the world to help (or sometimes hinder) your progress. Each play through I'd race for a backpack which allows you to store an additional item as well as the one you have equipped, The only thing that is persistent between playthroughs is a bank balance which you can use to save money for purchasing items and upgrades, the bank can also be used to store an item for future playthroughs and purchasing discounts, life insurance and a last will. If you die with the last will in your possession all money on your person is deposited to the bank.

The duration of a playthrough will depend a lot on your play style; I tended to edge around corners slowly picking off enemies one by one and found playthroughs to be between 40 minutes and an hour but it is possible to complete a run in less than 10 minutes (according to the leaderboards!). The reward for dispatching the final boss is a fresh $5000 in your bank, Whilst I mention the bosses, I felt the final boss was a bit two easy once you figure out how to take him out and would clear the room of other enemies before finishing it off. The level 4 boss was a bit more tricky, but eventually you develop the skill to take it out with relatively little damage received. 

Overall, Heavy Bullets feels like a fresh take on a huge genre and felt very different to what one would expect of a FPS. It's psychedelic colour scheme and upbeat music make it feel like a strange trip and aside from minor disappointment with the boss encounters its up there in terms of a single player FPS/roguelike experience.

review: I first off want to say, This game is harder then it looks. I havent even made it past level 2. This makes me like it even more. I think that it is worth the money, even the 10$ that I paid for it. If you think this is too much then wait for it to go on sale. worth the wait.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132154407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1609961761}
review: Heavy Bullets is very interesting, incredibly fun to play, somewhat scary at times, and wonderfully neon. It is simple, yes, but very nice and also unforgiving af. It's difficulty makes it fun and what it lacks in appearence, it makes up for in play. Instead of focusing on the textures one the walls and floor, you worry about the possibility of being attacked when turning the corner. It is *so* fun to play and I love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076219837', 'num_games_owned': 3116, 'num_reviews': 296, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1507428873}
review:
Si estas leyendo esto... es porque probablemente estas en la página de la tienda de este juego y... seamos honestos... si entraste en esta pag y decidiste leer los analisis de usuarios... estas interesado en el juego y por lo tanto prefieres los juegos con "interesante" estetica y  jugabilidad del sobre los "graficos"... y este juego cumple eso... a medias.
Lo bueno:
+Simple, pero no facil, como todo rougelike (moderno) este juego es simple de comprender, pero dificl de dominar.
+Estética inspirada en los videos musicales 80teros.
+Mayormente libre de bugs (esto es un plus para juegos indies)

Lo malo
-La IA es algo simple
-El contenido que ofrecen por 10 dolares es muy poco.

Recomendacion
Si realmente quieres este juego, espera que salga en un humble bundle o en una summer sale por 75% (o más) y disfrutalo, este juego eventualmente cansa y dependiendo de quien seas, lo vas a terminar en 1 semana o a abandonarlo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150474638', 'num_games_owned': 2260, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1522488605}
review:
[h1] «Наївний, ти думаєш звідси є вихід?» [/h1]
З фільму «Той що біжить лабіринтом»

Як тільки я запустив цю гру, я одразу згадав фільм «Той що біжить лабіринтом», і не випадково, бо у грі нам запропонують бігати по випадково створюваному лабіринту. А що являє з себе ця гра?

[b]Геймплей:[/b]
Гра являє з себе рогаликоподібний ФПС-шутер. Нам потрібно ходити по випадково створеному лабіринту(а ходимо ми дуже швидко), вбивати ворогів, збирати гроші і йти в наступні двері до нової частини лабіринту. У грі не запропонують стріляти на ліво і право, бо у нас лише 6 патронів до револьвера (і сам револьвер), які на щастя випадають з ворогів на землю після пострілу. Наявно багато ворогів, і кожен з них має особливу поведінку яку варто вивчити для подальшої боротьби з його братами. З ворогів випадають монети які можна скласти у банк, або підійти до терміналу і у терміналі купити нові патрони, аптечку, бонуси і інші речі які допоможуть пройти лабіринт. Вся суть це пройти з першого рівня лабіринту до 10 рівня. Відповідно на 4, 8 і 10 рівнях нас чекають сильні і великі боси.

[b]Графіка:[/b]
Поглянувши на стіни і ворогів, ми не побачимо краси і реалістичності. Ми побачимо райдужний сплав кольорів і відчуємо себе дійсно у грі. Адже у сучасних іграх графіка майже як у житті, а тут ти відчуваєш цю гру, відчуваєш що саме так створено гарну атмосферу. 

[b]Музика:[/b]
І звісно атмосферу гри доповнює музика. Швидка і кислотна музика асоціюється з графікою і є невід’ємною частиною гри. А цю чудову музику  час від часу розриватимуть рики монстрів, звуки пострілів і білі шуми які попереджують про босів.

Над сюжетом розробник навіть не думав, бо його тут немає.

І ось у висновку у нас безсюжетний рогаликоподібний шутер, який створює навколо себе атмосферу і затягує у себе на декілька вечорів.
Оцінка:7/10 важких патронів

author: {'steamid': '76561198080488200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1537192327}
review:
Ein sehr buntes und interessantes Spiel. Normalerweise habe ich für dieses Genre überhaupt nichts übrig, dieses Spiel hat mich aber definitiv überzeugt.
Der Graphik-Stil ist zwar etwas gewöhnungsbedürftig, wenn man aber erst ein paar schnelle runden gespielt hat, dann fängt man sehr schnell an ihn lieb zu gewinnen. Besonders toll ist es, wenn man die ersten Runden spielt und langsam merkt, wie man sicherer wird und sich nicht mehr so ängstlich in dieser bunten Hölle fühlt. Bei gab es eine richtige Verwandlung vom Gejagten zum Jäger, was ziemlich cool war und was dem Spiel viel wiederspielcharakter verleiht. Auch überrascht das Spiel mit neuen Gegner- und Leveldesgins. Das Spiel kann aber auch ziemlich unfair sein und ist ziemlich schwer.
Trotzdem eine unbedingte Kaufempfehlung!

author: {'steamid': '76561198086779137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1501988167}
review:
[My score out of 10 is at the bottom if you don't want to read this]

I will be quite honest here.  When I first saw the screenshots for this game, I nearly laughed.  Most of the time they try to show screenshots on Steam that make the game look better than it is.  The sad fact of this game is, the opposite is true.  If you are turned off from looking at the screenshots, think again.  This game actually does have a unique and cool art style that looks too flashy and annoying from the screenshots, but in reality works great in this game.  This game brings a lot of challenge as soon as you start playing with limited bullets that you have to manually pick up and reload after shooting.  The enemies are simple yet well designed.  Although this game does not have a lot of depth and really no story, the fun  and replaying factors are off the scale.  Even after your health drops to zero and it is game over, you will want to play again.  Not to mention the fact that each time the levels are different since they are randomly generated.  There are a lot of other cool features about the game like a banking system and cool power-ups, but I will just leave my review there.  Overall, not a perfect game but a very enjoyable one that is a great time-passer!

[Character Design] 8/10
[Game Design] 8/10
[Gameplay] 9/10
[Fun-Factor] 10/10
[Game Balance (Items, Cash Given, Ect.)] 9/10
[Story] Not really any, sorry

~FINAL RATING~ 8.8 out of 10  
                     ---> Is it worth it at full price? YES!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971976560', 'num_games_owned': 376, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 692, 'last_played': 1529587876}
review:
J'ai fait un run de malade mental, transporté par les graphismes simples mais flashy, évitant et tuant les monstres plus ou moins gros qui voulaient me boulotter. J'ai looté, j'ai connu la fortune, me permettant toutes les fantaisies possibles et imaginables en termes de level-up. J'ai saboté les tourelles de défense à tir automatique, découvert des passages secrets, suis passé de niveaux en niveaux grâce aux trappes fluo, le tout transporté par la musique. Même si le jeu n'est pas très équilibré au niveau des items, malgré sa difficulté, je me suis senti tout puissant. Omniscient. Omnipotent. 

Et j'ai fini tué par un verre de terre avec des dents.

10/10

P.S : Il m'a fallu plus de dix heures pour venir enfin à bout du premier boss. "Bon chance".

author: {'steamid': '76561198030876612', 'num_games_owned': 1475, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1430994083}
review:
Heavy Bullets'ı ilk kez yabancı bir yayıncının yayınında görmüştüm. Oynanışı güzel görünüyordu ancak grafik tarzı pek hoşuma gitmemişti. Roguelike Sale sırasında indirime girdiğini görünce alıp deneyeyim dedim ve o zaman farkettim, Heavy Bullets çok keyifli bir oyun. 

Grafikleri rahatsız etmiyor hatta gölgelendirmeleri ve anti aliasing seçenekleriyle çok daha güzel bir hale geliyor. Tabi oyunu güzel yapan ne grafikleri ne de müzikleri. Öncelikle oyun roguelike bir oyun, yani her bir yeni oyununuz size başka bir macera sunuyor. Bir The Binding of Isaac olmasa da düşmanlardaki ve silahlardaki çeşit bolluğu da bu maceranın derinliğini arttırıyor. Diğer güzel yanı da oyunun hızı. Oyun sizden başka shooterlara göre daha hızlı olmanızı bekliyor ve size yeni bir deneyim yaşatıyor. Heavy Bullets için Paranautical Activity'nin yapmaya çalışıp da yapamadığı her şeyin doğru yapıldığı bir oyun diyebiliriz.

Artılar, Eksiler
+Bol bol yaratığa ve eşyaya sahip
+Oyuna alışmak kolay 
+Yeniden oynanabilirliği yüksek
-Grafikleri herkese hitap etmiyor
-Bazı eşya açıklamaları yetersiz, deneme yanılma gerektiriyor (tabi bu bir eksi mi artı mı size kalmış)

Sıkıldıkça açıp oynayabileceğiniz bir oyun. İndirimde bulursanız kesinlikle alın, oynayın.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043291439', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1708238207}
review: Being a long time fan of the Hotline Miami series, I thought I would try this game out. My friends recommended it to me, and at first, I thought it would just be a simple fps dungeon-like game. However, it is very fun and very addicting. You are able to pick up every bullet you fire, but must reload each bullet individually. Enemies drop money, which is used to purchase items, weapons, gear, and medical supplies at various vending machines scattered arond the randomly-generated maze. There is also a banking system. You can deposit money into a bank machine, and withdraw it if you die and restart. This aspect adds a bit of strategy to the game. You must decide if you should spend all of your cash right away, or deposit some in case things go wrong. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a stylish, fast-paced, arcade shooter, that gives off a very nostalgic vibe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024976479', 'num_games_owned': 526, 'num_reviews': 194, 'playtime_forever': 277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1518762083}
review:
Without a doubt, heavy bullets is probably the most stylistic "rogue-lite" (I refuse to call it a roguelike) on the market right now. Does that make it a good game? 

In Heavy Bullets, you're basically playing a person whose goal is to do something about the security system, but honestly the story pretty much ends there. Other than some really strange flavour text that pops up whenever you start up the game, there's nothing else to the story other than you're going around shooting spiders and turrets.

The "music" (more like sound) and graphics are beautiful. I have heard some people complain about the colour palette, and while I sort of agree at some parts mainly I think it's pretty to look at and the sound fits perfectly. There's usually no soundtrack in the background unless you beat a level or walk up to a vending machine, which even then is only glitchy ambience instead of actual full on audio tracks. When you're almost dead, a intense drum beat starts playing which amps up the tenseness (is that a word?) of the game.

That's where my positives mainly end. While graphics and sound are a big part of this game, the other is the gameplay- which unfortunately is not spectacular. The picking up bullets mechanic is at first, very interesting and fun until you realize that you're either going to be stuck at basically swimming in bullets, or no bullets at all and no way to proceed (which is amplified even more by another thing that we'll get to later).

But what's wrong with the mechanic? Isn't the point that you get punished for bad aim, and that you have to risk your life to go grab more? That is all fine and dandy- until you realize that it forces the game to become a slow, methodical almost stealthing game rather than the fast "shoot or be killed" shooter that the game's movement speed and controls hint towards it wanting to be. Moving fast and shooting fast FEELS good, but you get punished for it so harshly by the enemy design and the nature of dropping bullets that you are forced to camp behind pillars and take your shots slowly- something that would work better for another game, but for the twitchy controls of Heavy Bullets it just feels like it bogs the game down to unplayable levels.

In turn, this all creates a loop of camping and inching to preserve bullets and then running out of bullets because you're camping, making you have to camp harder and be even more careful as you try and make a sneak attempt to the bullet you dropped, probably ending up in your death unless you got a bunch of health to camp with or bullet magnet+ to grab it from afar. Overall, I don't think that this mechanic is pulled off well mainly because the dangers that are presented to you are too high to make the game that fun "run-n-gun" game it wants to be so much.

Other problems I have are more nitpick and personal preference- I honestly feel like the banking system kind of encourages grinding and money grubbing more than actually enjoying the game the first times through; although you don't have to play the game like this, and there's even an achievement for ignoring it altogether. I feel like also some of the items are death sentences, I've never used running shoes without me running into a snake and killing myself and bombs seem like they're kind of on the useless side of weaponry even though you get a lot which ends up balancing them out somewhat.

So, do I recommend it? Well, if it's on sale as it currently is for 2 dollars, I'd recommend it just for the graphical and audial experience, but otherwise I'd say no. The trailer of popular LPers screaming at snakes attacking them is basically all this game boils down to- being killed by hidden things as you camp in corners trying to hold onto your bullets.

[b]TL;DR:[/b] Heavy Bullets is an extremely pretty game game that adds a few innovative features, but squanders them by wanting to be both a slow stealth-like game and a fast run-n-gun, making your twitch based controls and movement basically useless as you inch around levels hoping a snake or turret doesn't kill you around a corner as you camp behind pillars. Get on sale for the graphics/audio, avoid on non-sale price because the gameplay is kind of bad.

5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197983613557', 'num_games_owned': 458, 'num_reviews': 222, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1648959033}

I recommend this for all shooter fans.

SPEEDRUNNING IS IMPOSSIBLE.
Currently I am #11 in BEST WIN TIME
The lag spikes are random and unforgiveable. There will be a lag spike just when you enter a room and you will die. This is the biggest sin when it comes to this game, which is strange given the player's high movement speed. You are inclined to believe that the game loads just as fast as you run but no...

author: {'steamid': '76561197977703126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1430000644}
review:
If you've played Receiver (you know, that game made in a week) then it feels like someone took that game's concept, mixed it with Binding of Isaac, and fleshed it out to make it a full game. Seriously. It even has the shoot the battery thing to kill turrets from Receiver.

Overall the results are enjoyable, but not much about it stands out. Unlike the other 'roguelite' FPS it really and truly has 100% procedurally generated levels, which is something that Ziggurat and Paranautical activity cannot say. But even so the challenges the game presents you with rarely combine into a serious threat. Once you get used to the game you will rarely be hurt unless you get RNG'd with a bad turret placement or the suicide bug bombs. Game's worth it for $2 at least.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035353084', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 737, 'last_played': 1473264941}

review: I must say, this game is pretty fun. I am not normally interested in any type of FPS game, but this is certainly an exception. And it sure does get the blood flowing. As you continue there are more monsters/robots, and variety of monsters increases as well. Not to mention the neon maze you travel through, which closes sections off occasionally. I've been freaked out by snake worms and flying imps way too many times. On the technical side, I'm impressed by how the game has support for so many inputs, ranging from mouse and keyboard to PS3 and Xbox360 controllers. Nicely done.

review:

Make every shot count, and don't panic. Or do panic, I think it makes it a little more enjoyable.
8.5/10 Very fun, but makes my colorblindness bug out at times. Bullets are indestructible as far as I can tell, but when you fire half of your rounds at a faraway turret and miss the power box, well... the fact that they're bouncing around isn't very helpful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051363041', 'num_games_owned': 232, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1481981281}
review:
I picked up Heavy Bullets during the roguelike sale for $2, and I suggest that everyone should, even at full price. It's another one of the "fps roguelikes" that seem ever so popular these days, with a very retro feel.

The first thing about the game that I noticed was extraordinary was the quality in audio and visual feedback: coins and bullets jingle on the floor, enemies clearly alert you through sounds when they're around corners, and worms scare you shitless as your screen shakes and a loud bassy sound drops when they attack from behind.

 Although "retro", it manages to keep the player very immersed in the game, both with sound and mechanics, which is something games like Spelunky and Isaac tend to fade from doing as you get better and better at them. This may be good or bad, depending on how much immersion you're looking for from a roguelike.

Mechanics are very in-depth, with magnets for coins and bullets, homing bombs, and even the ability to invest in a discount on all other items, a "last will" that saves your items and consumables on death for your next run, and a "life insurance" investment that lets you keep money on death for your next run.

Finally, as far as performance, it runs great; maxxed, including FXAA, I get about 100 on a GT 640 / AMD FX-6100, which is a rather budget setup. There should be very few FPS issues, likely even on laptops.

Overall, it's a very different experience from your average roguelike, and I love it.  If you enjoyed Paranautical Activity, Receiver, or Fancy Skulls, give this game a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038949819', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1702853683}
review:
EDIT: To elaborate a bit on my review, the problem with this game comes from the massive disconnect between the core gameplay loop and the bosses. 99% of this game is very slow and methodical - you peek around corners, aggro enemies and let them come to you, try to snipe the turret power boxes while staying behind cover from the gun, etc. When it comes to the bosses though, you're LOCKED into an arena with minimal cover while the boss IMMEDIATELY wails on you before you can get your bearings. The slow and methodical game loop does not prepare you for the fast and frantic bosses, and the speed at which they dish out death makes it very difficult to learn from them. Perhaps the devs intended the core game to be fast and frantic too, but if so they completely failed with the AI.

Original review:

I like almost everything about this game.

My one peeve is the bosses - particularly the final boss. Coming into it for the first time, without knowing what's ahead of you, you're almost certainly going to get slaughtered. It's somewhat annoying to have to play a further half an hour just to get a second go (I beat the level 4 boss without getting hit on my second run through - much easier when you know what to expect), or for another hour or more for a second go at the final boss (who killed me so fast the first time I STILL don't really know what to expect going in again). I think giving the player some way to observe the bosses before jumping into the fray would help, because at the moment you practically need to resign yourself to the fact that, if it's your first time reaching the final boss, you're only half way there. You need to gather as much info as possible before you're inevitably killed so you can stand a chance the second time around.

But like I said, everything else is stellar. Highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097705575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1540774277}
review:
This game is fun, but there are a few things I didn't like about it. If this game is currently on sale, ignore my cons and buy it!  It's a good game to pick up cheap!

PROS:
Challenging
Rogue-Like
Cheap fun
A unique game for a familiar genre
Good music (see cons)
Pleasant art style
Can run on a potato without being ugly

CONS:
The music doesn't play constantly throughout the game
The story makes no sense
Enemies are too predictable
Enemies come in little variety
OMG the turrets are OP
Turrets can only be killed with bombs
Bombs are rare
If I turret is close to the next level door and you have no bombs, you can't proceed
Map is too straight forward 
Gunplay is unsatisfying

7/10 solid game, but I'd recommend buying it on sale.

EDIT: after playing more, I realized that the turrets can be killed if you shoot their battery. My bad. Turrets still are annoying little buggers though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022087448', 'num_games_owned': 606, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1489698389}
review:
I thought I'd like Heavy Bullets, because I like FPS and Roguelikes.
Sadly I don't.

The premise of the game, to have to pick up your bullets after firing them, seems novel until you realize that we've had this mechanic dozens of times with bows and arrows.

The real issue with the game is that deaths feel really cheap.    

There are turrets that have a glowing box that you need to shoot to take them out and they fire fast projectiles at you as soon as they see you and they track you through walls. This means that you need to move at max speed to pinpoint the spot and then pre-shoot after peeking from a wall. The game does have quick movement, but there are snakes hidden in the brushes that bite you if you come close, so you shan't move fast. Conflicting signals.
After seeing a turret, it shoots at you within half a second, which means you'll lose HP even if you instantly shoot it.
Having snakes wait around 90° corners feels cheap (they rarely make a sound).
There's a "Repellent" item that supposedly repels snakes, but it just makes them more aggressive.

You start with 3 grenades and besides the bullets, it's the only item that doesn't occupy "the" item slot, so you'd assume that they're a core part of the game. Most of the game plays quickly, but the grenades fly slowly and the throw distance is abysmal (am I playing a T-Rex?). 

Most items use up that one item slot so you end up leaving lots of items behind.

Technically the game has no excuse why it doesn't run at a constant 120fps. There's hardly any geometry to render.

Bullets and coins on the floor make sounds and jump around, which makes it easy to pinpoint them and is useful early on, but it becomes a nuisance later when there are dozens of coins on the ground, which mask enemies in their noise.

The environment has no variety at all, which makes backtracking to a vending machine very confusing, as you can easily get lost in the repetitive rooms.

There are banks where you can drop off your gold so that you can use it in a future run. It feels like they're excusing the unfair difficulty by giving you a way to grind currency.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044010429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1529555564}
review:
At first I had some technical problems with pink box startup, but aside from that, I have got to say the only 2 hours I have logged in has surged me twith instantaneous fun. Compared to some games in my library, it was well-worth the purchase. I love the revolver system; blasting away the monsters with a big ol' reusable silver bullet never felt so right. Personally, I liked color scheme. It has a certain allure to it that has me reminiscing hardcore lasertagging. Randomized labyrinth has you wondering if the next corner revelas another shop while you regret not reloading facing the laser to your face. The rage of dying to the snakeworm has me wanting to go back and shoot'em again and again. Definitely great for in-between loot-grinding session, or breaking away from the MOBA stress ladder.

tl;dr : Fun-filled rave-colored rage-inducing shooter

author: {'steamid': '76561198042254599', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1328, 'last_played': 1429488614}
review:
I love this game.  I LOVE this game.  It's a first-person shooter, if you're into that sort of thing, with a semi permi-death thing going on.  It's rogue-like, and it has some gnarly colors (a good thing).  The soundtrack is sparse and electric, but pumping at times, which is surprisingly effective--it's quiet at times, but then it rolls up from the background almost like it knows things are going to get rough.

The enemies are a mix of almost trivially easy and ridiculously hard, though you won't see the hard ones for a handful of levels.  Everything except the bosses dies with one hit, which is good, but you're still going to have trouble, especially when confronted by groups, or when you have to hit a weak point.

You're forced to rely on items and upgrades, which is a pretty neat system, except that you'll lose them if you die, in all but a handful of circumstances; that could be a dealbreaker for some, and a challenge for others.  To say more would be giving away too much.

If I had to find flaws with the game, there are two big ones:

- It gets annoying pretty quick when you die over and over on the same boss, which can be hard enough to the point where your beating it is largely luck.  Should you actually beat it, and die later, you're stuck starting from the very beginning.  It's a near rage-quit.  In the same vein, sometimes your items will save from one game to the next (the result of an item), but sometimes they won't, despite having that item.

- The bigger problem for me is the frame drops.  It's not a terribly demanding game, and I have a decent system, yet, whenever I play (and I always have Steam's frame rate counter running), there are multiple times where the game will drop from 60 FPS (you can change this in the settings) to ~52 or 53 FPS.  It seems slight, but when you're playing a twitchy game like this, and the frame drop causes you to get snagged by an enemy, (and it happens ALL THE TIME, enemy on the screen or not), it's enough to really piss you off.  I've tried all the different permutations in the settings:  FPS caps on/off, shadows/vsync on/off, FXAA on/off...you name it, I've messed with it.  No change.  It's always just enough of a drop to screw you.

All in all, I give it a 7.5/10.  Worth the price, absolutely.  Fix the frame drops, and I'd give it a 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004053899', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1449125102}
review:
Fast, fun, and absolutely brutal. Oh, and it looks like you're on acid the entire time.

The primary feature of the game is that bullets, when fired, can be collected from the point of impact, making them a very precious resource. Mook enemies die in one hit, so it's mostly a game of reflexes, but you still won't get very far if you Leeroy Jenkins your way forward instead of taking the time to properly approach unexplored areas.

Very simple and fun, certainly worth a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061019858', 'num_games_owned': 501, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1429326802}
review:
Heavy Bullets is a Rogue-Like FPS where you have one objective: Get to the end of the security mainframe to stop machines and creatures from killing the clients of your company, and yourself.

It's a very simple game. You are armed only with a Revolver, and you need to survive the 8 levels of the hunting grounds where various creatures and machines lie about to kill you. Your revolver can kill everything in one hit, and is 100% dead accurate. There's no bullet time travel, it instantly hits whatever you point at. You only have 6 bullets though, so you need to pick your bullet back up, and reload it back into your gun (Which is also instant with a press of the R key.)  Enemies will stop at nothing to chase you once they have you in your line of sight, but they drop coins which you can use to buy various items.

Many items and stations exist to help you along the way. Lots of items are hidden throughout the floors, or locked away in doors that require keycards (Which you get from killing certain enemies), so you should do some searching around the area, you might find something good. You have items that bring up passive effects such as taking one hit without losing health, resistance to explosions, or a backpack for additional storage; or they can be weapon items such as mega bombs, mines, or rockets. Other items are handy tools. Speaking of storage, you can only hold one item at a time, so you need to make your choices carefully when you have to pick from 2 or more items, unless you have the backpack, then you can hold two items.

There are 3 stations: Banks are the most important ones. You can store your earned money into the bank for future use when you die, you can also store items in the bank for another run. You can withdrawl money from whatever you stored, and you can buy a last will, or life insurance which'll transfer a percentage of your money on-hand to the bank when you die. There is also the Medbay station for healing items, and Bullets (And Stuff) for weapons and other weird little items.

This game is permadeath, so if you die, you're sent all the way back to the beginning, but there is the Bank station to help you out on your next run. It kinda brings a thought of "should I store money in here now for better runs next time, or                    withdrawl some money from my current bank so I can have more help on this run?" Same thing does for storing items, too. It's a bit of decision making when you think about it, so be smart about what you do.

It's not an easy game, either. Everything (Besides immobile turrets) charge directly at you, and aren't afraid to get in your face. You need to make your shots carefully because you only have so many bullets before you have to reload, so accuracy is a must for surviving large encounters. That means don't freak out; keep a cool head. Making it all the way to level 8 and beating the boss will be quite the challenge.

Overall, Heavy Bullets is a pretty unique rogue-like with it's fast paced nature of your insta-kill revolver, the metroidvania vibes of searching for items, and the strategic thinking of the bank and what items to bring with you. I think you'll find quite a bit of enjoyment out of it, and it's cheap too. It's something to try out sometime.

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197978608285', 'num_games_owned': 2480, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 849, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1624049613}
review:
Update: I got good so here's a bit more to add to my previous review (see below):

This game is a hot mess, the AI activation from enemies will always cause frame drops even on 2021 top tier GPUs and CPUs, it's not your PC it's the engine.

If you can handle that, which isn't too hard to do if you clear stages methodically (slow as fuck) then you'll enjoy this game.

I would not recommend it though anymore having beaten it thoroughly. It's not an awful game, but it is a bad one.


Initial Review:

Much much harder than I expected.

Just getting to the midway boss can be nerve wraking.

I haven't beaten this game yet but I would still recommend it to anyone who wants a challenge and enjoys the difficulty of rogue-likes.

The visual and sound design are a treat and the gameplay itself consistently has me coming back to attempt to get past my best run.

A challenge seekers game for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152400635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1557274597}
review:
Cautious lack of recommendation, I'm sure there's still content to discover, but so far I'm a bit disappointed by how thin this nevertheless very interesting FPS/rogue-like feels. It succeeds as far as atmosphere goes, especially on a sound design level. It's retro chip-tune design feels threatening in an almost abstract sense, with some hidden monsters in the grass only being given away by the little blip noises they make, though of course you also have sounds to signal uncollected items and jaunty tunes to tell you a kiosk to make purchases is nearby. It's a really terrific use of sound design to fill in the visual holes. 

Gameplay wise, the hook is gripping. Instead of collecting masses of bullets like most FPS's, you have to make due with a limited number of bullets that can be recovered after battle, and only one kind of gun. You can also collect bombs, but run out of both and you're basically done for. The problem I have is that there's really only one strategy for each fight; run out, listen for enemies, run back, wait for them to follow you around a corner, dispatch them, then poke your head back out and deal with turrets carefully. It's possibly an inherent flaw with smushing rogue-likes and FPS's together, since the former is based on randomization and making due with what you have and the latter is much more dependent on strong level design. I feel a lot of those flaws could be compensated for with stronger RPG elements, but leveling up is so far not that involved. You can buy or acquire more bullets, upgrade health, purchases a backpack to carry more than just one item, and of course find items that make you run faster, heal, or give you a melee attack. But in a game called "Heavy Bullets" there's no way to upgrade your gun or your bullets. Certainly I'm sure a lot of this has to do with the game's creator being a single individual, but I wonder if scaling down to a top-down shooter or even just making it a survival arena shooter and focusing on the gunplay wouldn't have made for a better game.

In any case this is by no means a bad game, so give it a try yourself, and I'll keep chipping at it to see if there's more depth than is immediately apparent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056439289', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1564200532}
review:
It's not often that I'm excited to play a game. Sure I can look forward to it- but never that excitement I'd feel when I was a kid and there was a new arcade game at our local dinner place, or when a new gameboy game happened to be released. Heavy Bullets gives me that excitement to play. Its fast paced, unforgiving, and often the hardest part of the game is not getting too full of yourself. One false move, and you suddenly are out of hearts. I'm thankful it doesn't cost quarters to play, otherwise I'd probably be on the street for the number of times I've replayed since purchasing.

With the vending machines and smart banking that carries over to new characters you can choose to play a few games and save, or go all out and buy all the upgrades. There are numerous ways to play this game, and every time I end a game I wonder how I can do it differently.

A fantastic game and absolutely worth every penny.  Frustratingly fun, and always leaving you wanting more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968140801', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 851, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1436823360}

author: {'steamid': '76561198029112749', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1527793887}
review:
Heavy Bullets is a random generated and neon colored shooter, since I hate it to write summaries I'll just give the list with good and bad things :) .

GOOD
- Very original, you wont be able to find a game which offers the same experience as this one!
- Great atmosphere, maybe the graphics are not very realistic but that's oke. Everything is 8-Bit style including graphics and music, totally different from other games in this genre.
- High replay value, becouse the maps and item positioning are totally random.
- Challenging, you won't be able to finish the game within 15 hours.
- Every enemy has his own strenghts and weaknesses, which add some strategy in the game.
- Cheap, it's below €10,- and I even bought it in sale ;) .

BAD
- Most of the maps are almost the same, which can be repetive.
- You loose your progress when quitting in the middle of a level, exept when you quit when you finished a level.
- Limited amount of enemy types.

CONCLUSION
Just buy it, it's totally worth the full price and for that small price you get a whole new game experience you never met before.

8.5/10 I'll recycle my bullets again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136872060', 'num_games_owned': 481, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1433720013}
review:
Минималистичный, но чертовски забавный и увлекательный рогаликоподобный боевик с занятным подходом к стрельбе. Вместо того, чтобы дозволять палить в белый свет, или напротив, вынуждать игрока горевать о каждом бездарно потраченном патроне (как это сделано, например, в Teleglitch), здешний принцип напоминает мне о проведённом в детстве времени с пневматикой: стрелять потенциально можно сколько угодно, но за пульками (в данном случае - пулищами) изволь всякий раз сходить и подобрать.
Удачной охоты, [i]и осторожней с кустами - змеи, они повсюду[/i].

author: {'steamid': '76561198012089036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1425600683}
review:
Heavy Bullets stands out like a neon buoy in a sea of generic rogue-likes. The garish art style may seem gimmicky, but in fact perfectly complements the vivid, nightmarish tension of hunting in The Highlands. In fact, the bizarre color palette and unusual enemy shapes serve an important purpose - to reset your perception and your ability to discern friend from foe. An experienced FPS player may welcome this departure from artisic norms as a means to retrain their reflexes, and those who love fast-paced FPS combat will find Heavy Bullets' frenzied bursts of action to be quite satisfying. The reusable ammo system adds a layer of skill and strategic depth while avoiding RNG-based ammo generation issues. Even sound is a critical element in the game, as different SFX help you predict enemy movements.

Sadly, Heavy Bullets suffers from highly repetitive level generation. At least half of the items in the game are fairly useless, and the same can be said for many of the upgrades and extra weaponry. Although not inherently bad, the player's bullets are not projectiles in the traditional sense - should your reticle center on an enemy's weak point, they will die the moment you squeeze the trigger, regardless of distance or movement. Additionally, enemy aggro relies heavily on line-of-sight, making it easy to pick off enemies one-by-one in most rooms. These atypical mechanics add to the quirkiness of the game, and feel very appropriate amongst the other design choices. 

Heavy Bullets is best-suited for roguelike fans, who will love the tension and atmosphere that it offers; however, it is possible that those who pick this game up for other reasons may find its permadeath and repetition a bit more of a grind than they can bear.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995322134', 'num_games_owned': 360, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1431823605}
review:
It's a rogue-like, so if that's not your forte, then you can move along.

For those with the open mind, this may be my favorite game--visually--from last year.  It's bright colors mediate the somewhat sardonic tone of the "plot" (small snipettes of text written in random places) and the monster, while terrifying when they sneak up on you, are adorable.

Overall, it's a lite game, yet I can tell already I'll be pouring hours into this beast.  It isn't an "action" game so much as a survival (rogue-like), and you have to be careful and somewhat strategic with your limited resources or else you'll lose it all.

For people needing numbers, it's an easy 8/10, and for its price, it'd be disgraceful not to at least give it a try!

author: {'steamid': '76561198084977938', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1425160334}
review:
2015 EDIT AS OF 11/4/15
So, the developer has dropped this game and ran. After people complained enough in the forums, he finally said he was releasing a "fix" in the next coming weeks, which from what I can ascertain, never came out. So people pestered him on the forums some more, he said he'd try to get it out in the "next week or so" after it never came out, people, again, questioned him on the forums. What did we get? Nothing, and it's been like that for a few months now. Don't buy the game. The developer has given up on it. A shame too, it was a perfectly good game. Goddamnit, this happens too much to good games. F*ck you, developer.




















OLD REVIEW
NO LONGER RELEVANT, LEAVING IT HERE FOR ARCHIVAL PURPOSES ONLY.
-----
This game really takes a meat cleaver and cuts of all the fat surrounding the "Rouge-like" 
catagorization.
The game itself is simple, yet odly fun.
You go into the game, a suppposed security failure has happend and security turrets are opening fire on customers to the hunting grounds, you were sent into to, yep, basically kill everything. This game is just great, I don't see how it could get better.
Maybe another gun?
Hey, but that's just me.

The game itself is very simplistic graphics and style wise, and has a very dungeon-like feel, what with the 3 hearts and such.
The game itself is difficult, increasing each level, i myself got clusterf*cked by turrets on the 4th level.
All around great game, I usually play it if i'm bored or want ti oass some time, amazing game.
If you want a rouge like game, that dare I say is actually a ROUGE LIKE, buy this game, 
10$ Is a great price for a game this beautiful

author: {'steamid': '76561198049270936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 1410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1542607296}
review:
Oh my god...
This is like Delver meets Hotline Miami. Its perfect. The game doesn't always play fair, doesn't hesitate to assume you're an absolute wizard, and challenges you to the bitter end. As someone who's gotten all the way to the end of level 7 (and died right at the exit), I can assure you that despite how well you think you know the game, your arrogance will end up biting you in the ass. Heavy Bullets will destroy nearly everyone who attempts it, up into even their 20th run. And that's a good thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048176962', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1422077376}

review: Charming roguelite shooter, excellent music, presentation and gunplay. Replay value can be a bit low after you finish the game, but I still got a solid 6 hours out of it. Recommended if you can pick it up for 7,50 or less!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970406584', 'num_games_owned': 905, 'num_reviews': 300, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1421775946}
review:
Best FPS of 2014, the mechanics are deceptively simple, and at very first you think it's just gonna be repetitive, if a brief distraction, but then you realize that it's actually not quite that shallow. Just managing your, very limited inventory, is a minigame in itself. Do you expect to die, and grab a Last Will? Or do you decide that this is the playthrough you're aiming for a win on, and bring a Cursed Gem or similar powerful boost item?

The enemies are also simple, at first, but when you hit mixed groups, you start realizing that they really mix a lot of simple factors into something fun, emergent fun! Snakeworms aren't a problem on their own, sure, but when you gotta watch out for them in the underbrush while blasting imps and dodging turrets, suddenly they up the difficulty scale.

It's a game that's gonna hurt you, and be unapologetic about it, but every single time, you'll realize it's your own fault, not the game being bullshit. Which means you're going to keep returning to it.

So it's basically like spousal abuse but fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974232769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1550985488}
review:
If you get this game, you will soon know the Hate and Fear that Snakes inflict upon Indiana Jones...Except, you aren't an archeologist; You are a Janitor. A Janitor navigating a seemingly LSD inspired Jungle Maze filled with Turrets, Snakes, and some other odd looking creatures. Who would put a Janitor through this?! Highrise Hunting Grounds...That's who...Atleast they leave things around to help you out, like a Boom box, and Highheels...?

This is a good game, rather fun and addictive due to its simplicity and randomization. It may feel odd if you aren't used to the old school FPS style, but it works well for this game. It isn't an overly long game, but one mistake could cost you the run. There are item pick ups among other things to find, which add an element of luck as well to your runs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066310712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 4078, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1605, 'last_played': 1646463037}
review:
If you like first person shooters that are built to look like old polygonal acid trips into an underground blacklight safari then you'll like this game about shooting demons in a turret filled worm forest of NEON polygons.

The levels are randomized each time.
Permanent deaths make you play each game like it's your last.
The game teaches you to sweep like a goddamn SWAT team member.
Increasing difficulty and fatigue from multiple tries gives the game real challenge rather than frustration from bad controls or unbeatable foes that other games will give.

4.5 Zap Zone Monsters Out of 5

author: {'steamid': '76561197964772360', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1420134187}
review: You have a 6-shot revolver to destroy enemies with, the bullets from which remain in the environment and can be retrieved after. It's super simple, but very challenging, fun and puts to great use the whole concept of risk versus reward. Defeated enemies drop coins which you can use to purchase items and upgrade yourself with, but once you die...you die, this is a permadeath game and defeat means restarting again from level one, however you can boost your next playthrough by depositing surplus coins in the previous life at banking terminals randomly placed in each level. Levels and enemies are also randomly generated, so there's no chance of gaining the advantage by learning the corners and hiding places, you have to be alert at all times, and even when you feel completely confident in yourself, something unforseen will usually spring out of nowhere and put you in your place. The more you advance, the more you stand to lose, can you reach the final level? (I certainly havn't...yet). Love this game, you might too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130499824', 'num_games_owned': 96, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1588016057}
review:
Heavy Bullets é um jogo de tiro em primeira pessoa com uma perspectiva muito original , e jogabilidade dinamica .

Enredo :
 em uma analise reduzida do enredo , uma emreso com algo como minas no subsolo , esta tendo problemas com o sistema de segurança q acaba por matar todos os clientes , e funcionarios que vao ao local , que agora esta infestado de criaturas que se assemelham a instetos e os funcionarios de digamos um cargo mais alto oferecem uma recompensa de $5000 para quem for ate a 8ª camada do subsolo e restaurar o funcionamento das maquinas de segirança  , sem se importar com as vidas que serao colocadas em risco , apenas fazem os funcionarios antes de partir assinar algo em relaçao a negaçao de direitos , como inimigos do jogo a os

* IMP : uma animal de cor escura que corre na sua direçao na tentativa de mordelo . 

*Cobra : que se camufla em plantas e o ataca o deichando envenenado oque faz com que voce perca vida com o passar do tempo e que só é anulado com o antidoto. 

*Vespas : sao como os IMP porém com asas 

*Arrastador: sao IMP com garras que sao usadas para se proteger dos tiros e que causam maior dano .

*Torretas : sao o proprio sistema de segurança , robos que morre apenas se voce acertar no nucleo de força (caixa verde que esta sempre ao lado deles ) 

*Inseto Bomba : uma especie de frambosao (aparencia de fruta) que corrre suicidamente em sua direçao e explode .
entre outros inimigos 

a também os itens que vao desde um poçao para regenerar vida ate , um bombas  ,cada qual com a sua utilidade voce só pode carregar um item por vez entao varia com o estilo de gamplay do jogador .

a mecanica da gameplay é muito interessante pois o jogador pode recuperar as balas disparadas pela sua arma, que só tem capacidade para seis delas. Quando o usuário atira, seja para atingir um inimigo ou em uma parede, a bala cai no chão e fica disponível para que ele a pegue de volta e recarregue uma a uma manualmente. Ou seja, munição é um elemento de extrema importância aqui, então, faça cada tiro valer a pena!. 
 Ao longo das fases voce se depara com caixas eletronicos e lojas fixas uma maquina onde pode comrar mais balas iten e etc (por sinal nome das lojas fixas tem o nome de "balas e etc..) ja nos caixas eletronicos voce pode vender itens , depositar seu dinheiro  para caso voce morrer reiniciar com dinheiro e ter uma certa facilidade , alem do mais vc ainda pode comprar testamentos , e e o "seguro de vida" 
  Em Heavy Bullets a morte dos inimigos é facil porem a sua também pode ser caso nao tenha a "tatica" certa me cada fase ,alem do mais quando voce morre nao importa em que fase esteja voce volta direto para a primeira (por isso é muito util depositar o seudinheiro) 

Opiniao Pessoal :
Heavy Bullets é um jogo de tiro em primeira pessoa que traz alguns elementos bastante originais para um estilo que envolve sobrevivência, gerenciamento de recursos e um bom nível de habilidade. A jogabilidade é bastante simple.
O fato de ser necessário recolher as balas e recarregá-las uma a uma adiciona um grande nível de desafio ao jogo. A experiência se aproxima de um survival, já que o personagem é perdido, caso sua vida chegue a zero.
Este fator é o que pode ser considerado o maior ponto positivo. pois graças a ele o jogo fica bastante dinamico e requer muita habilidade e sua cota de experiência em horas de jogo para chegar cada vez mais perto do mainframe a cada nova tentativa.
Os gráficos possuem um estilo não muito detalhado e repleto de cores vibrantes em neon.(ala Antichamber) Apesar de ser um visual muito bacana para algumas pessoas pode encomodar ou dar um certo desconforto .

é isso , no geral gostei muito do game , apenas tive que me acostumar com as malditas cobras com as quais voce tem que conferir cada planta para nao sofrer um ataque "surpresa" 

Rcomendado o/
...

author: {'steamid': '76561198119533238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1453500749}
review: Heavy Bullets is a unique, rogue-like FPS game that has you on your toes as you are guided through a randomly generated map with different foes to face. As you make your way through different levels, you have vending machines at your disposal to buy items and bullets. Why bullets you ask? You start with a revolver and 6 bullets (this is where the "heavy" part comes in) and you are forced to pick them up after you shoot them. It's fun, it's colorful, it's just so cool! I really enjoy myself when playing heavy bullets, it provides a fun and interesting challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132095787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1434824720}
review: Okay, I love this game! It's so easy to just pick it up and play when you only have fifteen minutes, or you can easily lose a couple of hours to it. It's simple, but addicting. The huge amount of items and their rarity in certain playthroughs kept it interesting, but there doesn't feel like a huge penalty when you die so it stays fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055205810', 'num_games_owned': 1022, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1689394006}
review:
Free the imps.

Edit:
This game is wonderful because it's definitely an original idea. I haven't put many more hours into it since I first bought it, but that's because the Holiday sales are times whenever it's ridiculous and my cash well practically runs dry as far as spending is concerned.

But this game is original. Check into some gameplay videos with it. It's a dungeon roguelike game that is randomly generated. It gets harder and harder as you go along. It's definietly a game that tests your reflexes, or at least that's what I gather. I enjoy it a lot and actually did begin to feel sympathy for the imps whenever I progressed through the game. 

With all this being said I would recommend this game because I can definitely see myself putting more horus into it because I haven't beaten the final boss and I think that it is reasonably priced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039283793', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1433284420}
review:
Procedurally generated rogue-like with it's focus around shooting, but more interestingly, taking care of your bullets and not wasting a single round by picking back up every shot you fire. Gather coins to buy items and upgrades, and invest in inheritance and the ingame bank for when you inevitably die, so that your earnings may be passed down to your next character.

The assortment of various items from pills to power ups and the treasure rooms you find them in bears an uncanny similarity to the Binding of Isaac which I really enjoy, so if you like that you may enjoy this game as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098179292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1437679977}

author: {'steamid': '76561198005312887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1438866146}
review:
It is a compelling game, and I've had some fun with it, but ultimately there is a better experience to be found with this game's competitors.

Heavy Bullets has decent enemy variety, and I like the art style. The shooting and re-usable bullets mechanics are not great in my experience, I would have preferred more variety. The bombs that you can throw are very hard to hit anything with and generally seem useless, so you're just going to be sticking with the revolver for the majority of the game. Items might be interesting, but I have no idea what any of it does. Some are self-explanatory, but what does a golden skull do? I just played a run through with one, and I have no idea what it did, if anything, because the game makes no attempt to tell you. I don't need to be spoon fed, but at the same time I do need information if I am to understand what stuff does. So I picked up some repellant, what does it repell? You can't test it by hanging around the various enemies, because you will end up getting yourself killed, and the game doesn't tell you one way or another.

The ease at which you can get screwed over by the game is not balanced with enjoyable game play, in my opinion. Stressful, tense game play is welcome, but there aren't any "fuck yeah" moments, no moments of "that thing I just did was awesome" to balance it out. There are also technical issues, if you are considering buying this game check the forums before you do. Currently (and for a while now) there is a bug causing really bad frame skips that can really screw you over if you happen to be trying to shoot something at the time. The aiming reticule is also not locked to the centre of the screen so it jiggles, and for some users wanders quite far from the centre making it hard to be accurate.

It's not a bad game by any stretch of the imagination, and maybe on sale it's worth a look but I can't recommend it in all honesty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130514798', 'num_games_owned': 1423, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 1252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 599, 'last_played': 1679803839}
review:
[b]tl;dr: GAME IS BROKEN[/b]

I loved this game, I really did. I loved the entire aesthetic, the enemies, the randomness, and the hair-pulling frustration.

I loved this game to pieces when it still worked, which is why it's so hard for me to give it a thumbs down.

The game is broken in a way that is just subtle enough to make it next to impossible to beat. It stutters every once in a while and the view lags behind where the player actually is, causing unnecessary YASD and frustration. All because the dev refuses to fix this broken game.

Hundreds of people have complained about this glitch. The dev knows about it, but have left the game to rot for [b]over a year[/b]. Games that have such a serious glitch shouldn't go on sale. I'm at my wits end. Maybe a stream of negative reviews will get them to fix it, but they already have my money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999203798', 'num_games_owned': 340, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1681150412}
review:
Simple yet stylish, First-Person, Rogue-like excitement. Not quite enough gameplay elements here to make me fall in love, but I do consider this game a good friend. 

Textures? Who needs those. Leveling? What does that even mean? What this game excels in, is bringing you to laser focus upon rounding each new corner, and mechanics that encourage you not to look back. 

Currently it has some glitchiness: there are many, many frame dropping freezes, especially when "seeing" an enemy after a lull in the action (I have actually lost my best run due to the game freezing my character and magically making my bullets go thru enemies, all at 4 fps).

With some consistent development, additions to the mechanics, and polishing out the bugs, this game could become a 5/5 Star beaut.

Best of luck to the stylin' dev(s).

author: {'steamid': '76561198014665763', 'num_games_owned': 1991, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 94, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1415917690}
review:
It's not that Heavy Bullets is a bad game, it's just that there are much better games out there. Heavy Bullets feels bland and monotonous compared to games like Tower of Guns and Ziggurat. Perhaps it's the single weapon, perhaps it's the lack of enemy variety. It may be the extremely basic and unappealing graphics; I can't quite put my finger on what makes Heavy Bullets so boring in such a short amount of time, although I suspect it's a bit of all of those things.

In any case, as mentioned above, buy Ziggurat or Tower of Guns instead; they are much better games.
